data.name: Nagasaki Memorial to Korean Victims of the Atomic Bomb

reviews.text:
평화공원 올라가는 계단 옆에 있는 중국인 추모비와 조금 비교된다. (설립 추진자 및 위치 등)

Hard to find this small creature. While Chinese memorial stone indicates itself being supported by China and Japan, this... only has few North Korean phrases in description in front. poor condition, should be taken better care of by some strong organization.
The English is faded or scrubbed off.
Many of Korean was lived in Nagasaki area because of forced labour. Their miserable life had ended by nuclear bomb.

May the victims rest in peace. Have a glass of water brought from the Korean peninsula and a refreshing glass of makgeolli. How painful must it have been in a land so far away. We will make sure that our descendants will never forget that sacrifice and strive to create a better Republic of Korea.
Of course, this is an important place for Koreans, but was it intentional to put all the memorial stones for foreigners, including Koreans, near the bathroom?

Super Hero Ryoma was here.
How awesome is that 😂
It had bee the office for Sakamoto Ryoma's company.

It is built on the site of Kameyama Shrine, said to be Japan's first company built by Ryoma Sakamoto.
The honorary chairman is Tetsuya Takeda.

You may take photos of the small garden, replica kimonos, and guns, but it is prohibited to take photos of the original materials such as letters displayed in the back room.

When you see the remains of the dirt floor and the attic of the actual mansion, you will be immersed in the thought that Ryoma and his friends were really in this place.

In the summer, a good course might be to climb the stone steps from Megane Bridge, cool down at this memorial hall, and then head to Kazagashira Park.

If you're walking up the mountain, it's a good idea to remember to bring a towel and hydration.

I visited it on February 1, 2024.

The site and memorial hall of Kameyama Shachu, a trading association formed mainly by Ryoma Sakamoto and said to be Japan's first stock company.

I had to climb some very steep stairs to quite a height, and my legs became like sticks due to the sweat.

Unfortunately, I arrived late and it was closed. If I have a chance, I would like to visit again.

There is a back road that you can drive up to, and there seems to be a paid parking lot.

At the end of the Edo period, if you like Sakamoto Ryoma, you know Kameyamashachu.
amazing! It may not be much, but you can feel the history, and you can also take a photo with Ryoma Sakamoto.

If you like Ryoma, you should go there at least once!
You just have to find a parking spot and walk. Finding parking is a little difficult.

data.name: The monument of the first railway in Japan

reviews.text: Many people think of Shinbashi when they think of the birthplace of railways, but in reality Nagasaki seems to come first. Now there is only a stone monument and it is a bit lonely.

Passing by, really? I thought.
I really want to.

I heard that Glover ran a steam locomotive here for the first time in Japan.

Now there are only stone monuments, so there is nothing to see.

Nagasaki was also the first place in Japan where bowling was played.
I was surprised because I thought it was Shinbashi Yokohama.
The third birthplace of the day, no trace left

data.formatted_address: 1-1 Huis Ten Bosch Machi, Sasebo, Nagasaki 859-3243, Japan
data.name: Huis Ten Bosch

reviews.text: I have dreamed of going to Huis Ten Bosch Theme Park for a long time. Thankfully I finally had the chance to visit this spectacular place. The hotel I chose there was the Europe Hotel. They have a park cruise that takes canals through a picturesque European village to arrive at this hotel. As you go through the entrance you are surrounded by roses and their delicious fragrance . The outside gardens are also filled with blooming graceful roses. Their fragrance overflows into the streets and embraces the visitors. As I walk among the roses and the tunnel of roses my heart jumps for joy and I feel like a princess walking in a beautiful garden. I love the amazing light show in the evening. Overall I love this whole experience. Amazing place to have fun, relax and enjoy.

Theme park for adults. There is still plenty for kids to see and do, but, this one is GREAT for adults and couples looking for an enjoyable getaway. Of course, it is not just the Dutch theme, it is the overall aesthetic. Most theme parks look like a cheap and temporary movie set (because that is what they were originally) but this park is all real. Disney and USJ use visual tricks to make the scale look larger, but HTB is all composed of authentic buildings. They even imported much of the materials from Europe. Honestly, the architecture is so impressive that many of the buildings would be must-see destinations if found anywhere else.
In addition to the visual appeal of the permanent buildings, much of the park is changed with the seasons. Each season brings a new look - Christmas, Spring, Summer, and my favorite, Halloween, where they go all-out and create an amazing interactive experience.
It is a theme park, so don’t expect bargain prices if you don’t want a cheap experience. However, with the Yen rate being favorable to foreigners, plan to splurge a bit and have a memorable vacation.

Beautiful park to admire! The ticket was 7,400yen for adult and you can pay by cash or card.

This place has attractions for children and many other digital attractions like a digital aquarium. The porcelain museum was interesting. Lots of food options and good to go early else you’d have to queue.

I was there more to soak in the vibes of the place so didn’t head to too many attractions (you have to queue too).

Rent a bike! It was the best 500yen spent for an hour of electric bike. The staff speak English too. Pay up front and return the slip of paper to them when you return the bike. Be careful when riding it as it accelerates quickly when you peddle and could be dangerous if you fall into the water canal.

They don’t have an English map for the whole place which was frustrating as I have to download yet another badly designed Japanese app just to find out the locations of the attractions and activities. Might have missed the physical board at the entrance but I found it somewhere near the middle of the park in the end

I spent around 4hrs there and it was just nice!

Huis Ten Bosch was a mixed bag for me. The gardens and scenery were nice. But, man, the entrance fee was way too steep. And, let's be real, the indoor rooms smelled like old carpets - not a great vibe.

The food was also expensive, and the parking fee was just the cherry on top. It's a shame, 'cause the place has potential. For 7400¥ adult entrance fee, it's equal to Universal Studio Singapore price but what we get is so different 🥶

Some toilets are so smelly and old, not all but most.

Pros: Beautiful scenery
Cons: Expensive entrance, smelly indoor rooms, pricey food and parking

Would I go back? No

Huis Ten Bosch is a relaxing, beautiful theme park that's light on rides but heavy on ambiance.

This park is ideal for a weekend date/getaway for couples, young families or retirees that just want to hang and enjoy the beautiful scenery.

Some of my coworkers mentioned that for a long time this theme park was on the decline, but new management has come in and completely reinvigorated the whole place.

I don't have any one particular recommendation inside the park, but the whole place is great for just aimlessly wandering around and getting lost in.

I went with my wife and daughter when she was just two years old and we've all been hankering to go back ever since.

I was here for a workshop which limited my ability to experience all that it had to offer, but I found it to be great. Located right on the coast, the beach is nearby, the resort is wide and has shuttles and bikes which help in moving around. The rooms are spacious and fun for families as well.
This resort is fantastic. The facilities is lovely.  The night trip is memorable to my kids. Food is fairly good. We would rather spend more time in Ark land Spa.

Great resort with lots of family friendly activities included, plus more you can pay additional to enjoy.  Bike around the island, go fishing, enjoy onsen, darts and games.
Stays can include meal plans

Really awesome resort, however, due to COVID so many things on the property are closed and it takes a way from the experience a bit. Otherwise, I can’t imagine how great this resort is with everything open. It is also awesome that they have bikes that you can use at any time to go all over the island.

A wonderful family friendly resort. Kids loved it!

We stayed in Kaze Hotel side where the rooms are dated but very large. It’s not so much a problem as there’s so much to see and do around the resort. The highlights were the Ark Spa, bike hire, dinner at Iojima Shokudo, and breakfast at Minato Diner. Lots of useful facilities like the convenience store and free cafes.

An enjoyable stay.
Had a bit of fun playing in the Jurassic area..it was a nice experience.
Great half day out with a boat cruise through some nice scenery. kids & adults alike love the AR dinosaur hunting

One of the most recommended, unqiue place in Huis Ten Bosch. The AR shooting gun experience was full of fun! Could see lots of sea and islands view by taking ship to here. Might get some chance to see dolphins, but we just see a fish jumping out of the water far away.

Althought the staff said Japanese, and we could barely understand, there is still one member know that we are foreigners and show us the translated language instructions that we could understand.

However, there are so many mosquitos on the island, so it's better to wear long sleeves clothing. Also be superly careful when using the AR shooting gun, since you could easily fall over by the ground which is slippery, moist, full of fallen leaves, and some place is near the slopes and stairs.
It’s fun to play…

My child wanted to go there, so I was reluctant because it was a 40-minute boat ride each way, but it was a good decision to go. The ship moved slowly, so it didn't shake that much, and the staff on board explained things to us, so we arrived in no time. The sea there is very beautiful and it's an uninhabited island, so that alone is exciting. The staff made it fun, and even though I'm not very good at games, I was able to have fun participating. At the end, the staff took photos for us, creating another fun memory for our family. If you are going to Huis Ten Bosch, I highly recommend you to participate at least once.

data.name: Adventure Park

reviews.text: We got there late afternoon at a discounted price and had a lot of fun!
More for older kids like teens, its fun nonetheless!!!
Fun place to go

I feel like this is the place that families with children go most often in Huis Ten Bosch.
There are many active attractions, especially Shooting Star, which I love and do every time I go there. Why are there sometimes unusual wait times? That's what I thought, but I felt like there was a lack of equipment.
We are also looking forward to the new attraction, the Sky Rail Coaster, which will be in operation from March. This can be found in the Fairy Tale Mysterious Forest across the street from the dinosaur objects.
Back in the sky, Castle in the Sky is a popular athletic course, ranging from a 3m high course at the children's and family level to 6m for the intermediate course and 9m for the advanced course.
There are also various other attractions such as a three-dimensional maze, a fluffy slide, and a free fall slide.

postscript
The sky rail coaster is too much fun.
I want you to ride it both day and night.
You can also interact with guinea pigs and rabbits.

It's an adventure park that seems to be visited mostly by families with children, but I think the Tyrannosaurus rex in the dinosaur forest at the entrance is quite noticeable even during the day. If you're staying at Henn-na Hotel and want to go home after watching the parade at night, you'll have to pass through the adventure park to get back to the hotel, but the road is quite dark, so the Tyrannosaurus is quite impressive. Become. Even adults would be surprised if one suddenly appeared on the street at night with a snort, but the child almost cried a little.

reviews.text:
YOKERO is difficult...!
Hardware looks easy when you look at it from the outside, but it's difficult when you try it.
I tried to avoid the lines of light by jumping, but if I lost sight of the whole thing, the game was over in no time.
The staff carefully taught us the timing of the jumps and how the lights appeared, but it was still extremely difficult.
Even if you have excellent athletic ability, we recommend that you try the harder part first and then move on to the next step.

There is an attraction facility called YOKERO. It's very popular.
We recommend that you obtain numbered tickets in advance.
Difficulty levels from Sports onwards are quite difficult.

At night, the buildings on both sides are lit up, creating a magical space unique to this area.

It can create a strong sense of symmetry!
Plus light up at night! !
Thumbs up

An attraction facility located in Fantasia City of Light.
Athletic Fantasia is one of seven state-of-the-art digital attraction facilities in Fantasia City of Light.
You can have fun moving your body and playing with the light.
It takes 10 minutes.

It is divided into YOKERO and SKY FLOOR.
YOKERO is a digital athletic that avoids hitting the flowing white line. You can choose the level after practice, so you can enjoy it while increasing the level little by little. However, it's difficult to repeat because it's so crowded, so the sports level seems to be moderately enjoyable.
When I looked up, I saw a net and that was the SKY FLOOR. It's not crowded here.
SKY FLOOR, which is 4m high, has chairs and balls suspended from the ceiling, and you can enjoy athletic activities using your body by using them or jumping on the net. You can also enjoy watching people playing YOKERO from above.
Shoes and pants are also available for rent, so women wearing skirts can also enjoy the experience.
When you exit, take the tube slider to the first floor.

reviews.text:
I watched the project mapping for 10 minutes and was impressed.
The sound effects of the dance organ are impressive.

I watched the project mapping for 10 minutes and was impressed.
The sound effects of the dance organ are impressive.

An attraction facility located in Fantasia City of Light.
Art Fantasia is one of seven state-of-the-art digital attraction facilities in Fantasia City of Light.
When you enter the building, you are greeted by a large, heavy-duty dance organ (an automatic organ, or mechanical organ, which is an organ that plays music automatically rather than by a musician).
Currently, there is no sound, but you can enjoy projection mapping centered around a dance organ that covers the entire field of vision.
Let's enjoy the mysterious world of sound and video♪
It takes about 10 minutes.
There were not many tourists, so the performance started immediately without any waiting time. It is in a reserved state.
You will not be able to enter midway through the performance, so you will have to wait at the entrance once the performance begins.

This is an attraction where projection mapping is performed on a large street organ (imitation) on the wall, and you have a designated seat to sit and watch it.
The level of projection mapping was quite high and it was very impressive, and I was captivated by the link with the music.
Even if you're tired of seeing projection mapping, I think there's something about it that makes you go, "Wow!", so if you don't have a long wait, I highly recommend stopping by.
I didn't have much of an impression so I don't remember much ★2

A vintage organ that no longer works will be restored to its luster through the power of projection mapping.
It's really moving to be able to feel the history of the organ.

The application of light is really great. Many themes are great. My favorite is an old automatic music machine that plays three different tunes. Although each tune is very short, it can show it even more. difficult and precious

Another impressive thing is the flower-themed one. The interactive facilities inside are also very special. They use the places where people step on to create midsummer seeds. When the time is up, the entire exhibition hall will bloom with flowers. It is also very shocking. There are some places where you can smell the fragrance of flowers, which is really special. In addition to the visual feast, there is also the olfactory enjoyment.

There is also a more monotonous project inside, which is a projection project. You can listen to music and watch videos. If it is too hot outside, you can come in and take a break with the air conditioning, which is not bad.

There are seven fantasias.
I had to wait about 20 minutes in a crowded place.
It took about 5 to 10 minutes to get in.
It's fantastic and the images are very beautiful.
There are many photogenic places to see.
Taking photos is also fun.
It's sparkling and beautiful, but it's a shame that some of the equipment inside is visible. You'll be satisfied once you see it, so ★5

Opened in March 2021. There are six Fantasia facilities (Space, Flower, Caloyon (bell), Sea, Athletic, Art) and one cafe (Forest Fantasia Cafe). In Fantasia of the Sea, it was fun to watch the kids hold their hands together to make jellyfish. Popular facilities seem to hand out numbered tickets on holidays.

I visited on May 2, 2021. I went to Sea and Flower, but it wasn't my taste at all. I waited in line for 30 minutes in the heat for Flower, but it's not worth it at all... I won't come here next time and I won't recommend it to my friends. Is it ok for children? But if you have to line up, I don't recommend it even to children...It looks pretty in pictures though (^-^;)

reviews.text:
This is a seasonal event in Shirogane.
Palace Huis Ten Bosch appears even more fantastically at night.
Visited the park on a heavy snowy day. It was a literal silver promenade. There were no people around and I was able to enjoy it comfortably.
Winter only
Beautiful park. Located uphill. Accessible via stairs or via escalator. Lined with peace related sculptures from different countries. The centerpiece of the park is the blue peace statue..

The Mog Champ sends his regards.

The Peace Park in Nagasaki is the other side of the coin from the Hiroshima's Memorial Park. It's a sad moment in history which will always be remembered.

The Peace Park here is as peaceful as it can get, you'll see groups in their excursions visiting the peace man statue to get in their photos as well as your regular visitors. The place doesn't get busy and everyone is always respectful here.

Thank you for keeping the Peace Park beautiful and clean Nagasaki. I was glad I could pay my respects while I was here.

Mogliest Regards,
Your Mog Champ

Tourists: please remember why this is a Peace Park. It was built ten years after the bombing. Having your children stand in front of the Peace Fountain and making guns with their hands is INAPPROPRIATE. Teach peace, please.
A beautiful memorial park dedicated to peace after the atomic bomb was dropped on Nagasaki. Some beautiful sculptural tributes in the park from various countries.

After one of the darkest periods in human history, Nagasaki Peace Park is a moving representation of hope and healing. This peaceful haven, which located in the centre of Nagasaki, promotes peace, understanding, and the elimination of nuclear weapons while acting as a sombre reminder of the catastrophic effects of nuclear war.The famous Peace Statue, a massive bronze sculpture of a man holding up one arm in peace and pointing the other upwards to represent the threat of nuclear weapons, is the focal point of the park. Beautifully designed gardens, peaceful ponds, and meandering walkways encircle the monument, fostering a calm environment that invites introspection and contemplation.A wide range of monuments, memorials, and works of art honouring the remembrance of the Nagasaki atomic attack and the pursuit of peace can be seen all across the park. One of these is the Fountain of Peace, a beautiful monument with messages of hope and reconciliation etched on colourful tiles. The Children's Peace Monument, which honours the youngest bombing victims nearby, has thousands of origami cranes as healing and peaceful symbols.The Nagasaki National Peace Memorial Hall for the Atomic Bomb Victims, a sombre location devoted to remembering those who died in the explosion and conserving their tales for future generations, is among the park's most poignant elements. The memorial hall offers a potent and immersive experience that inspires visitors to consider the human cost of nuclear warfare and the significance of striving towards a world free from the threat of atomic destruction through interactive exhibits, survivor testimonies, and historical artefacts.Apart from its historical and educational importance, Nagasaki Peace Park is a thriving cultural centre that hosts a year-round calendar of events, performances, and activities. The park provides chances for visitors to interact with significant problems and take part in the continuous pursuit of peace, ranging from peace concerts and art exhibitions to talks and symposiums on nuclear disarmament.All things considered, Nagasaki Peace Park is a site of contemplation, healing, and recollection that welcomes travellers from all over the world to respect the memory of the past while pursuing a future full of compassion, understanding, and hope. It is a tribute to the human spirit's tenacity and a ray of hope in a world where the legacy of nuclear bombs still plagues us.

Located in the Teramachi (“temple”) district, this is the oldest Chinese-style temple in Nagasaki and is designated as an Important Cultural Property. Surprisingly, there was no one else, so it was very peaceful and quiet. It truly feels like something different from ordinary Japanese temples. There is an entrance fee, but it is definitely worth it.
Big piece of estate. Many temples, shrines and cemeteries dot the landscape. Lots of staircase to climb too. But the view from the top is peaceful and nice.
Beautiful shrine, cheap entry, quick to navigate, you can take nice photos

The grounds of this temple are so well kept and there is a lot of history. Admission was about ¥400 but it was worth seeing some of the artifacts and exploring the temple grounds. There are places to sit and relax as well.

Kofukuji Temple is the oldest and one of the most important Chinese-founded temples in Nagasaki. Located in the city's Teramachi ("Temple Town") district, it is the birthplace of the Obaku school of Zen Buddhism in Japan and has many interesting features.

Around eighteen meters of Dejima's waterfront on the north side was lost, owing to the rerouting of the Nakashima River. This led to the construction of a beautiful cantilever iron bridge in 2017 instead of the restoration of the old stone bridge.
Although not stated as such, this seems to have been a money making activity for the ruling shogun. I am guessing he got a share of every shipment in or out of this single authorized trading village.

A simple and elegantly designed bridge at the location where in ancient times the bridge lay between the "Dutch" island of Dejima and the Japanese mainland. The construction of this bridge somewhat restores the old situation.
A lovely little voyage to a simpler time in a small village dedicated to governance and storage.
Great place

data.name: Site of the Former Dutch Trading Post on Dejima

reviews.text:
Dejima is no longer an island owing to land reclamation. However, the restoration of buildings from the early nineteenth century (which include
living quarters, offices, warehouses and gates) offers a glimpse of the trading activities and way of life at the former Dutch trading post. Definitely worth a visit.

Well worth the 3 hours we spent there.  The cafe was fantastic.  Quiet and cool.  Food excellent and well sized.  Staff appropriately attentive.  Restored building were interesting.  Some of the exhibits became repetitive.
Probably nicer if you are from Japan and have not seen Europe. Being Dutch myself this site is more interesting of what it historically represents than what it can still show you today.

Dejima Museum with recovered building from Edo era. Dejima is an artificial island that functioned as an only trading post of Japan against the world during the Edo period. The surrounding of the island is already landfilled and no longer an island but you can feel the atmosphere at that time by the recovered building from different era.

Quite disappointed with this. While the main warehouse display was well done, I think for the rest, either their story telling was not good enough to pique my interest, or simply they had not much to tell since they were just participants in a Dutch story here. Don’t think it was worth the entrance fee.

Had a great time cruising the bay with Iwanaga-san. He took pictures throughout and sent them afterwards.

He offers 1.5, 3, 6-hour and overnight camping tours on the beach’s of nearby islands.

I haven’t kayaked in more than a decade, so I’m glad I chose the 3 hour tour - just the right amount of workout while being able to maintain a decent pace.

I’ll definitely be going back for the camping tour next time I’m in town.
Thank you for teaching me so kindly!

The water quality was excellent and the pool is easy to get to. 50m pools a bit shallow, making tumble turns a challenge. Pace clocks are lacking and the one present is not in the most convenient position. Overall I did enjoy the pool.

Large facility with 25m & 50m indoor pool. Showers could be a bit cleaner. Very helpful staff.

If you want to wear a smart watch or a fitness tracker, you have to cover it. Rubber covers can be bought for 400yen.

Swim caps are mandatory. If you didn't bring one, they lend you one for free.

Cheap and very pleasant pool to swim in both seriously and just to chill. I do wish they would can the cheesy radio, it can interfere with an otherwise relaxing place. Do Japanese need noise all the time everywhere?!
Good place to swim. Excellent support from staff.

＼Be sure to check business hours! /
In 2023, the opening time will be 12:00 from Monday to Saturday from July 21st to August 31st.
Even though the restaurant opens at 9am on Sundays and holidays, it's surprising how late it opens, even though it's the season.

In order for citizens to beat the sweltering heat and to make effective use of the facilities built with tax dollars, I would like them to be open (even if only partially) in the morning during summer vacation.

The facilities are splendid, and there's also a 50-meter indoor swimming pool for competitions, so there's no reason not to use it. The disadvantage is that there are times when it cannot be used for tournaments, etc.
There are irregular holidays, so we strongly recommend checking the website before going out.

Convenient parking is available in the underground parking lot next door.
Because it is shared with nearby sports facilities, etc.
There's no discount so it's not too bad.

data.name: Nagasakiken Nishiumishi Shirikusarikaihin Koen Camping Ground

reviews.text: A beautiful, small beach and camping area. Would be a nice and protected place to snorkel when it warms up. Bathroom facilities and outdoor showers available. People also spear fishing where the water opens to the sea. Camping spots are very close to each other so not much privacy, but would be great for families as car parking is within 50 feet of tents.

This seaside park is distant from the town and almost private beach but is crowded with many tourists during the summer.
If you would take and enjoy your time, I recommend to come here just after summer.
You can use hot water shower for two minutes per ¥100 if you make a reservation for the camp site.
Great campsite.  Great staff, highly recommend for a quick day trip or an over night.  Beach. Is picturesque!
Very bad and unfriendly camp owner. Even though there was lots of space we were send away nearing the dark. He must hate foreigners visiting Japan... Don't go here!
One of the very best beach in the prefecture. It’s a nice little bay with a sandy beach and gentle slope in the water making it perfect for kids.

data.name: Mt. Unzen Disaster Memorial Hall (Gamadasu Dome)

reviews.text:
Main message: the museum is built around the concept of reviving the disaster for the visitors and it does so VERY good with the volcano directly in sight and the museum built in the path of destruction. Texts are all in Japanese, but the audio guides are good and allow to dive into the exhibition.

Details:

We came in a little less than 2h before closing time on that day and basically had the whole museum to ourselves. The whole staff greeted us and we felt like on an official state visit. ☺️

The ticket machines are in Japanese only but the staff will help you if needed. At the entrance another staff member held a sign with English information on playing times for a cinema and a little theater (later more on that).

You get an audio guide in several languages. German an English are covered. I think Spanish and French as well. The guide is very helpful because texts at the exhibits are nearly all in Japanese. Just choose the number visible at your spot and press play.

There is little cinema playing a movie that replays the events of the disaster. It is in Japanese, but the audio guide plays translations and explanations in parallel. Worked for me.

Even better is the little theater! It replays the events of the earlier outbreak in 1792 with moving wooden scenery, sound, light and video clips. Made for kids I found myself leaning in totally consumed by the story. Absolutely lovely!

The do it yourself stations for kids are not fully usable if you don't speak the language. But this is just a minor glitch.

A highlight is the glass floor with a post disaster scenery. Every few minutes it simulates the outbreak and gives you an idea how fast a pyroclastic wave at 100kph really is. Frightening. 😬

There is also a volcanic stone walking path and a viewing platform. You could easily spend 4h there, I think. Cafe and vending machines are (of course) available and very affordable.

Very close to the museum is also a set of houses destroyed in the disaster and persevered in their state which gives you an even better understanding of the horrible force that came done back then. No fees charged there.

If some extra texts in English are added, the place is worth more than 5 stars.

I can only say: VISIT!

Didn't even know this existed. Happened here by accident on our through Shimabara to Nagasaki by the ferry. Saw the ad for the museum and stopped by. Very interesting and informative. They have free English audio guide.

This is a must-see if you are ever in the area. The story of the Mt Uzen disaster can really be felt here. It's completely amazing to experience. If you are an English speaker grab the headphones so you can listen to the story as you walk through each of the visual displays, it makes for a great experience.
A must see if in the area! Incredible exhibits and they provide English guidance!

The Mount Unzen Disaster Museum commemorates the eruption of the Unzen volcano between 1990-95. Multiple pyroclastic flows brought disaster and had huge implications regarding the safety of the local population. Costly measurements were taken to prevent future eruptions from causing damage and destruction. The huge concrete dry "river" bed covers the eastern flank of the mountain and channels pyroclastic flows and mudslides away from the city and into the ocean.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒852-8011 Nagasaki, Ōhamamachi, ３６４ 稲佐山公園
data.name: Mt. Inasayama Observatory

reviews.text: Beautiful view of the whole city.  I recommend in clear weather and preferably an hour before sunset.  This way, you will get a view of the city not only in daylight, but also if you can stand the night lighting.  The wind blows at the top and it gets colder in the evening.

Lovely view, but this is a venue which has become a victim of its own success. I arrived just before sunset hoping to catch both the day and night views, but you’re not allowed to drive to the summit anymore. There is a ropeway going down to the city (I did not catch this), and a monorail going down to a large carpark half way up the mountain on the ocean side. The monorail was modern and interesting, and cost 250 yen each way. Unfortunately, this also introduced significant delays so arrive early if you want to catch the sunset. There are cafes, vending machines, and a toilet on the summit. There are two viewing decks - one at ground level, and the other on top of the building. Whole venue is suitable for the mobility impaired. Parking is free. Last monorail shuttle is at 10pm. Definitely worth having a look, despite the crowds. Allow for an hour.

We got to the top, caught the bus up, and then walked another 10 minutes to the top.

It was complete white out cloud cover when we arrived, we almost left but decided to stick around for a while.

We sat down for a drink in the restaurant and 10 minutes later, the clouds cleared within what seemed seconds.

We then decided to wait for sunset, well worth the wait. The clouds completely cleared, and we were delighted by the city of lights. Truly magnificent.

Not what we expected when we arrived to zero view in the clouds. Patience can be rewarding.

The ropeway was closed. The other option I did was I drove up midway and toke the slope car to the top. It became crowded around evening time. I was there in the late afternoon but it was hardly anyone. I guess the night scene was more popular.
Stunning views over Nagasaki at sunset and in the evening. Get there early as it can get pretty packed. We were there on Fri night and drove up and were able to park before sunset.

Beautiful place! Other than camping, the park offers other activities: Fishing, boat riding and cycling (you can rent a bicycle and they have a bicycle trail that goes around the park). If you’re not into using tents, they have cottages/bungalow you can rent.
The campgrounds are wide and the washing area has enough sink that does not get crowded. The toilet was clean but has lots of insects.
The park’s office has a shop where you can buy souvenirs, wood, charcoal and food.

One of the best places I've ever camped. Good staff and good service plus reasonable prices. Shower rooms and clean toilets are available. A well maintained facility therefore I think it's very famous among people. There was a huge crowd doing camping but overall the place was very vast and there were many places to do camping.
This is a great place to visit with kids. Acres and acres of beautiful flowers, playgrounds, and awesome views of Omura Bay.

This is a nice quick getaway from CFAS for those of you in Sasebo. A quick 45 minute drive from main base, this camping/glamping site has great cabins and beautiful scenery. There's boats to rent and you can also fish in the lake. Take one of the many hikes around the 5 km lake with various off shoots to scenic lookouts up the mountain for various views. Don't forget to find the suspension bridge hidden on a short walk. A great place to take the kids where you can see a bunch of wildlife including lizards, fish, snakes and sometimes friendly stinging insects.

Absolutely scenically beautiful. The scenery deserves five stars but if you were to go there to camp to get away from people and enjoy nature I highly advise against it. At least on weekends or holidays due to it being extremely packed maybe less than 3 feet between tents although they do have cabins. All in all cool place to hike Trails everywhere and if you're forager also a great place for that or just the study of mycology.

The Chinatown in Nagasaki is really small and nothing to write home about. There are around a dozen Chinese restaurants and a couple of provision/souvenir shops along two narrow pedestrian streets. A leisurely stroll from the North Gate to the South Gate takes only 2 minutes.

Went here just to see the lantern festival which is held during the lunar new year. There were so many people on that day so it's difficult to go around and enter the shops. To go here, you can take the tram to and from Nagasaki station at ¥140.

Beautiful lights, got here at 8:45 just in time to enjoy it by ourselves before they close at 9. Came back the next day too. Smells soooo good. Just wish it was a little larger! But other than that it was enjoyable.
Quite a simple street with nothing special. Not worth to visit deliberately. The food is not impressive at all, copied Chinese style. Taste is so so.

Not impressed. It's a small Chinatown and all the stores have the same products, all the restaurants sell the same below average cuisine. It was nice to walkthrough but there are much more interesting things to do in Nagasaki. If you're in the area, it's not bad, but otherwise I would just not bother.

the place is beautiful with some history related to industrial area. nice to walk and stroll along while enjoying the view and the sea breeze. the place is uphill but don't worry since it got several sets of long escalator (love it!!😁). it also shown the Glover house and the inside of it. too bad we came when it was raining all day long. before arrive to the garden, we can find a lot of stalls that sells various things.

Pretty awesome place to pay a visit with family! You can enjoy the view of 長崎 here, and you can know the history of this beautiful garden. Besides, there are lots of ancient Japanese traditions stuff here and you can feel and understand parts of the old Japanese history. Pretty recommended.
Personal recommend: ★ ★ ★ ★ ★
Family-friendly: ★ ★ ★ ★ ★
Date for couples: ★ ★ ★ ★ ★
Parking lot: ◯ nearby coin parking
Services/meals/products/design: ★ ★ ★ ★ ★
Period for stay: 2 hours
Charge: adults 620/one person
Baby room/accessible toilet: ◯
Cleanness: ★ ★ ★ ★ ★

Beautiful place to visit for the day! Lovely staff, great arte acts, and the houses were well preserved. The travelator up was so convenient cos all the walking was downwards after. Minimal steps..as there were slopes mostly. The restroom was very clean too. Outside there is a street for some shopping as well. Highly recommended!

Really neat place with great views of Nagasaki. Many old western buildings were relocated here. It’s really cool to see the architecture and enjoy the views, but after going through it, I wouldn’t classify it as a “must-do” in Nagasaki as some travel blogs do. It’s cool if you’re in the area, but unless you’re really interested in Glover not imperative to go in my opinion. A couple of the buildings on the route are also under construction. It is wheelchair accessible.

This is a nice exhibit to see the residences of well to do foreigners (merchants and missionaries) living in Nagasaki in the 19th century. The complex is built with many western style buildings, mansions and cottages. On the way out there is an exhibition with the matsuri floats used in Nagasaki’s festivals. There are escalators to bring you up the top of the hill so that you can walk down at your own pace. There are nice views of the harbor from the porch of the main mansion.

Beautifull place to visit in your stay at Nagasaki city.
The view is spectacular, if you have visit some attractions will be easy to identify them (ok not all but the information notes helps a lot).
There're a restaurante, a coffeeshop and some 2 other places to eat (which were closed).
At Slope car station you find some deers and monkeys, a nice place to take children.
As I visited on Friday (12h30), it was empty and I could take some amazing pictures.
Beautiful view of the lights over Nagasaki. Truly looks like the Milky Way as described by the commentary. Worth the trip to see. Wish I could have also seen view in the day but no time.

Save this trip for the end of the day. The nighttime view is amazing. Restaurants at the top with good food and plenty of 360 degree view for your picture albums. There's a unique 2 car enclosed Railcar that takes you up the mountain.

This place is called the 10 million dollar night view but we went there during daytime. lol. Can be reached via ropeway, car, bus, or taxi. It was still a beautiful 360 degrees view from above despite being there around noon. Also, we were the only ones in the observation deck which was nice.
Like  Share

The view at sunset and at night is amazing. I got on the bus from the city center about an hour before sunset. For the observatory you can either drive up there and pay to pass a barrier or pay for the gondola to take up you up the last bit.

A must visit when in Nagasaki. ( This should be the first thing to visit when in Nagasaki.) As a tourist, it is an ideal place to give you an introduction about Nagasaki and what to expect around the area. Divided into 2 permanent galleries. Beautifully curated and interactive display. A good itinerary together with the nearby attractions-
Suwa shrine
Tetayama air-raid shelter(opens at 9:30am), and
Sto.Domingo Church Museum ( opens at 9:00sm)
- a good half day itinerary. The museum opens at 8:30am.

An interesting museum tucked away in a quiet neighborhood.

The museum is divided into two zones. There is a permanent exhibition of artwork, historical manuscripts and handicrafts; illustrating Nagasaki's rich history serving as Japan's window to the rest of the world during its period of  isolation. There are sections dedicated to the trade and cultural exchange with Korea, China and the West, in particular the Netherlands. The other zone consists of the Nagasaki Magistrate's Office which was reconstructed based on historical drawings and which can be accessed from the side of the building.

I really regretted going to the museum in the late afternoon. I was only able to finish touring the permanent exhibition (which took almost one and a half hours) before closing time.

interesting and informative museum located in a quiet neighbourhood. the staff were super friendly and there is a gift shop downstairs. we visited on a weekday and there weren’t that many visitors. a one-hour visit is sufficient.

unfortunately the english descriptions were limited, but enough to understand the gist of things (and they were provided on displays that were significant). i learned quite a bit.

i would highly suggest going to this museum first and then the atomic bomb one to put things in better context.

if you have a JR pass, you can show it at the counter for a little discount on entrance tickets. and don’t forget to get the commemorative stamp in the entrance hall!

Excellent museum well worth a visit. While visitors might focus on the atomic bomb museum, this very well curated and presented place looks more at the rich trading, history and cultural importance of Nagasaki.

The buildings are beautiful, exhibits informative and varied and many descriptions are in English.  They also include some real examples of the commodities that were traded, building mock-ups and plenty of models.

Also some good interactive and on-demand displays using a variety of technologies. Staff were friendly and helpful and spoke some English. Entry fee also very cheap! Highly recommended.

I had medium expectations and was pleasantly surprised! This museum, with interacting exhibits paints a vivid picture of Nagasaki from the 17th to 19th century, centered around trade and the connections between the city and the world. The beautifully reconstructed traditional building at the back is also very impressive.

Very sad but very important place for humanity.  A beautifully prepared exposition with the history before and especially after the event.  Everything is described in multiple languages.  Very instructive.

This place holds historical objects that are witnesses of the tragic atomic bombing in the tragic city of Nagasaki. There are also photos and videos of facts from that time. Being here really make me feels the deep sadness of innocent people who have become victims of war. I hope more people support the peaceful program

I went on a weekday afternoon and there were very little people.
The museum shows the haunting aftermath of the bombing of Nagasaki. It's walking distance to the park but you will have to climb some stairs on your way back.

This is one of the most spine chilling experiences I have had. I study this in history books, I have watched documentaries, movies and seeing it in person and being on ground zero is another level experience. It is a must when in Nagasaki! Let's hope that we have learned from this experience
one of the must see places in Nagasaki. there you will discover the details of what had happened when the city was hit by the atomic bomb. was teary eyed in the end.

Nice Tadeo Ando building with small but intetesting collection of Spanish art. Interiors are also beautiful. If you don't want to visit the museum you can just have coffee in the cafeyatia with a nice view.

The building itself looks great and the scenery on the roof garden is beautiful as well. Did not visit any of the exhibitions as most Japanese museums do not have English description. Didn’t bother to try

Nice museum, extreme dictatorship. I was approached by museum staff when I did essentially anything other than breathe and look at the art, including take a sip of my bevvy as far away from the art as I could manage and also take out a pen to write down some notes. If you like controlling, abusive relationships with authority, this is the place for you!
Picasso’s paintings is one of the collection here but photo taking is not allowed. The admission fee is 420 yen, permanent exhibition is quite small…

As someone who does not speak Japanese, you will not be able to read 90% of anything. Also in the parts that don’t allow photos, anytime I tried to take out Google translate to read the Japanese words, they stopped me thinking I was taking photos. Then only the temporary and special exhibitions were open so I don’t know why I paid for the base ticket if none of the public gallery was open. The whole thing took 15-20 mins to walk through because I couldn’t read anything. At least the rooftop space is pretty but not worth the price of admission

data.name: Nagasaki National Peace Memorial Hall for the Atomic Bomb Victims

reviews.text:
It is a place worth visiting. Be prepared to walk to see all of it. It is spread out but I feel every step was worth it.

Inside the museum it was very difficult to see what nuclear weapons do to a human body. This is a lesson for the world to heed.

This historical place is to commemorate the tragic incident of the Nagasaki city bombing in 1945 and how the survivors became living witnesses of this terrible event. This place also brings hope to promote peace and no more war

We were there twice.  Late in the evening when we were there completely alone and the place has a completely different atmosphere.  Then the next day, the park partly filled with school children and students.

Most interesting to dive into history and think of atomic war in general. Witnessing what happened to the inhabitants of Nagasaki with this unnecessary bombing.
A must to see if you come to Nagasaki.
A must visit when in Nagasaki. Very peaceful inside. Beautiful structure
More a shop than any museum. Do not confuse it with the Atomic Bomb Museum. If it is off your route, it is not worth a visit.
This is not a museum. It’s a small gift shop.
Not open  dec 26.
Strange museum.
Nice seaside restaurants

This museum has an amazing history and is very detailed. It can take a few hours to take everything  in. Its definitely  a must visit place for any Christian  who wants to see how Christianity entered Japan amd how it has survived and is being strengthened in current time.
The history was heartbreaking. It is worth a visit. For those stamp collector, there is a stamp inside the museum.

Historical place. ...to stand on the place where 26 true Christians died for their faith touched my heart. Their 30 day journey from Kyoto to Nagasaki to be martyred....their Way of the Cross.  I felt privileged to stand on the spot where showed their courage and love for Christ.

The museum is not that big, I stayed 1 hour because I really, really took my time since the entrance was 500¥. Everyone else that came in got out after 5 to 20 minutes. There were some impressive artifacts, but I felt like a good part of the exhibit was not specific to Nagasaki and what happened there.

Very informative and well structured museum showing the history of european missionaries (from home country Portugal) that came to Japan in order to spread Christianity. Their story is really well told and although it has an unhappy ending, the kakure kurishitan will always have a place in the history of Christ.
Small museum at a very nice place! Most of the displayed text is in Japanese, but leaflets are available in several European languages, including German and Dutch.
Nice interesting museum about a fascinating man.
Good experience

The Siebold Memorial Museum is famous for the ``Siebold Incident,'' in which it was discovered that he had taken maps of Japan that had been banned by the government.
Born in Würzburg, Siebold was a physician and naturalist who went to Japan during the country's isolation to study Japan.
Because he was from the Holy Roman Empire (Germany), it was difficult for him to communicate in Dutch.
In Japan, he was allowed to open a cram school outside of Dejima, and that is Narutaki, where the memorial hall is currently being built.
It seems that he introduced various Japanese cultural artifacts to the West and was known as an expert on Japan, but his decision to take out maps and other items that were of great military significance was a no-brainer, as it was an imperialist world at the time. All in all, I don't think he is a person who can be praised too freely.
After the expulsion measures due to the Siebold Incident were lifted, he returned to Japan and worked for various countries.
I stopped by to coincide with the Hydrangea Festival, which started on May 25th. I wonder what to do with the hydrangeas after the festival is over.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒850-0921 Nagasaki, Matsugaemachi, 4−２７ 長崎市旧香港上海銀行記念館
data.name: Former Hong Kong & Shanghai Bank Nagasaki Branch Museum

reviews.text: As a Hongkonger, I was surprised to see this monument building. It evidenced how prosperous was Nagasaki when it opened up to foreign investment from Hong Kong over a century ago. When I saw the decor inside on Nov 25, 2018, I could imagine the kind of activities taking place here then!

Well maintained building. 3 floors. A few interactive features, with English support. One floor had a lot of information on relationship of Sun Yat-sen & Umeya Shokichi. They have kept old furniture and some equipments (Morse code machines etc) in other rooms. Would have liked a bit more information on those exhibits.

Built in 1904, it was the largest Western style building in the city, decorated with ornament, arches and stone pillars. In 1991, restoration of this historical building began and was then re-opened as museum.
Opening hours: 9:00- 17:00
Admission fee: 300 yen

The museum has a lot of interactive features. Most of these support English speakers. I appreciate their effort in putting all these displays for a relatively cheap admission fee. Interesting place. Definitely worth the visit.

great museam with English, Chinese and Japanese explanations for exhibits, some of which are interactive. The building still has the old building feel. My only complaint is I was not able to look in either of the encyclopedia volumes they had there, which isn't too bad of an issun given the age of the books
A very beautiful building, many of its interior remains the same as original. Some history of the former HSBC branch too.
The atmosphere is very relaxed and inviting. I bought a few beautiful post cards as a souvenir of my time in Nagasaki.
A very cute and cosy picture book museum, with a cosy corner for browsing various japanese picture books, various art works,  and a cute store at the first floor.

Staff: incredibly kind.
Stuff: wonderfully cute!

Love that they have a wide array of English books. 🥰
You don't need to know Japanese to understand how unique this place is. That is the magic of illustrated books.

Beautiful picture book museum

Free entrance
Interesting small gift corner
I learned more about Father de Rotz's great achievements with the guidance of the sisters. Parking is available and nearby.

This is a memorial hall to Father de Rotz, who contributed to local medical care through Western medicine. Medical equipment and other items are on display, but although the memorial hall is open, the rescue center next door is closed...

It seems that the building will become part of the Shitsu Rescue Center.
The sardine netting factory and school designed by Father de Rotz himself is used as a memorial hall.

Although there are not many items in the collection,
You can touch reality.

It is located just a short walk from the Ethnic Museum, but it is difficult to find the location as there is no guide. This facility was originally built by Father Doro as a sardine net factory. Many relics and tools are on display here, including religious, medical, civil engineering, dyeing, and paintings. You can enter with a museum ticket.
It's not a big facility, but let's take a look.

You can learn about Father Doro's activities.
My understanding deepened as I was able to see not only the written words but also the clothes and agricultural equipment that were actually made.
A must visit place for all fans of 沈黙 (ちんもく),  Silence. The view is spectacular.
Love the FOC room for meditation.Sit here, face the sea and enjoy the quietness and reflect and looking inwards.
A very impressive place to visit in order to understand the background of the book "Silence".
I like his novel about religious.
Cute place to visit..
Great food and nice view of the Port
Free wifi

This museum is located on the 2nd floor of Shikairo, a landmark building in Nagasaki. Nagasaki = Champon noodles, and it is worth a visit as a museum where you can easily understand the history of Champon noodles and the origin of the name. There is a public parking lot underground in front of the building, making it convenient for sightseeing around the area.

This is the Champon Museum on the 2nd floor of Shikairo, which is famous for Nagasaki Champon. The main restaurant is crowded even before it opens, but this one wasn't that crowded.

The roots and origin of Champon, tableware, and a historical timeline are on display. I think it would be a good idea to visit before or after eating Champon at Shikairo.

I would like Nakatsu City and Usa City in Oita Prefecture to open something like the Karaage Museum. I thought it would be fun to open various gourmet museums in Kyushu.
Apparently this is the place where Champon originated, but I waited for about 30 minutes to eat it, but it wasn't as good as I expected. The view from the window is good.

data.name: Sotome Museum of History and Folklore

reviews.text: I went there and learned a lot about Saikai city.

Sotome History and Folklore Museum

In the Sotome area of ​​Nagasaki City,
The Shitsu ruins from the prehistoric period, the box-shaped sarcophagus from the Yayoi period, the Miyata tomb group from the Kofun period, the ruins of a workshop for making stone pots made of talcum stone used from the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura period,
It is also rich in valuable resources such as the unique history and culture of Christians under the rule of the Omura and Saga clans in the early modern period.

As one of the facilities of Shitsu Cultural Village
Opened in 1979

Sotome area
Introducing the history from ancient times to the present day, as well as the lifestyle and industry of the past.
Various excavated items and unfinished stone pots,
Including the Renaissance-era medallion Salvador Mundi (Savior of the World) brought by missionaries (a tangible cultural property designated by the city),
Valuable materials related to Hidden Christians and tools taught by Father de Rotz are also on display.

The history of the Ikeshima Coal Mine, which closed in 2001, is also introduced.
It's on a hill with a good view, and you can see the Shusaku Endo Memorial Museum in the foreground, and the Shitsu village and church in Sotome in the distance.

The second floor has hidden Christian heritage sites and an introduction video. The first floor displays a wealth of excavated artifacts and everyday tools from the Pre-Pottery period to the present day. If you are interested, our friendly staff will be happy to guide you.
The ticket here also allows you to visit the Father Dollo Memorial Museum.
A member of the church explained the origins of the church.

data.name: Nagasaki Museum for Human Rights and Peace

reviews.text: A hidden gem in Nagasaki. If you would like to know another side of history, please come here.

As a traveller, I am always eager to learn more about the history of a country I’m visiting, both the good and bad sides of it.

Many countries have scores of museums to showcase their triumphs but few, if any, institutions to display their shame. In India, I couldn’t find a museum that place any emphasis on the British colonial period, despite it being an important part of their past. In history museums across Vietnam, Myanmar, Laos and Cambodia, I’m treated to a series of propaganda that at times slip from the realms of ridicule into the chasm of comedy.

All of which is why I am grateful to discover the existence of this little museum in Japan. From reading some of the other reviews, I am also pleasantly surprised to learn that there are actually organised school trips to this place, even if those particular reviews didn’t take kindly to the museum.

After paying the cheap entry fee, the polite staff left me to peruse the two levels of the museum at my own pace. Interestingly, the stark contrast in the state and facilities of this museum as compared to the lauded atomic museum speak volumes on its popularity with the country’s administration. Nevertheless, this place still strives to educate with its few prop displays and tons and tons of information, half of which is fluently translated to English. The tone of the information might be a tad biased and accusing, but it’s easy to tune that out and focus on the content itself.

All in all, I had an enriching experience here and would highly recommend this museum to anyone interested to learn minute details in the inconvenient truths of war.

A frank look at the often omitted dark side of japanese history. Every nation have their own "skeleton in the cupboard", pretending they don't exist is a disservice to the otherwise glorious Japanese history and an insult to those that suffered, avoiding teaching about them is invitation for a future generation to repeat them.

the museum does a great job explaining Japan’s war crimes during WW2. It’s an especially important topic as tensions are rising between east asian counties and cooperation between Korea and Japan is essential. I recommend to any and all

The museum is not only an example of a rare kind of Zivilcourage but also as a remarkably welcoming and accepting space that puts the people before the labels. A must visit space, perhaps even more so than the memorial itself.

This place was truly unique. They have a historical collection of musical apparatus and music from Japan and worldwide. Additionally, a lot of stuff from the old times. It's exciting to review our past. You can also find José Feliciano and Julio Iglesias (Spanish speakers musicians). I loved old music, especially rock. So, this place was my heaven. It's not only the amount of music they have for exploring but also the experience of listening to them. The guides were very kind and helpful. Don't hesitate to ask them. There's one guide who can speak English. So, the place is friendly for foreigners. You can bring your food and eat there also.

Keywords: Relaxing, home feeling, history, tons of music, friendly.

In this place the time just flies. So, don't worry if you spend more than 6 hours there 🤭.
If you love music and quality sound, go here

Sweet little museum with a collection of sound producing machines that is truly awe-inspiring. The gentleman who was working when I went was bright, cheery, and very good at explaining everything in the museum in English to us, even though he thought his English was bad. Very beautiful museum , fantastic selection of music, and a place I am excited to visit more often.

The retro worldview is the best.
For an admission fee of 700 yen (though it may have changed since it was at the time of my visit), you can experience the world of the past and the world of records.
I'm not really interested in records.
Mr. Y was drawn a manga about this sound bath museum on X (formerly Twitter) by a person called Yukito, and I became interested in visiting it.

As mentioned above, I have no interest in records.
It was an irresistible space for me, who loves retro things, as I was able to immerse myself in the worldview of the past.
When you enter the facility, the manager will give you detailed information about the facility.
There are also things like phonographs, and you can come across things you've heard of but never actually touched.
They were very responsive and told me to let them know if I wanted to try working with machinery.

In what looked like a storage room, there were old documents and things like travel books, and there was a map from before the Great Heisei Merger that I personally came across. it's the best.

There are several rooms, and they will show you around, but at the end there is the largest record room (I forget the name), and if you ask them to play a song, they will play it for you.
This time, I requested the Carpenters' Top of the World, and I was impressed that even though the record was unknown, I was able to enjoy the music in such a magnificent environment.

In this day and age, even CDs are becoming less familiar, so it's a blessing to have a facility like this.

If you like records, music, or retro things, this is a facility you should definitely visit.
If you are a retro fan, you probably won't be able to stop holding a camera!

When I visited, there was a part of the road that was closed due to a landslide or something as it was in the mountains, so I ended up going there without knowing that and took a detour. We recommend that you obtain this information in advance.

A place I really wanted to go to.

First, you will receive an explanation of the facility.
You can then choose from a pile of records and actually play it on your player.

People who used to listen to music on records will enjoy it, but if you're just sightseeing and have no interest in it, it's best not to come, and I don't think anyone who doesn't have a specific purpose should go to this place.
I also want to be mindful of usage manners.

(You will have to drive for quite some time on a narrow and slightly steep mountain road to approach)

I don't have a lot of rare records, but I feel like I can ride in a time machine.

Lunch is a must for those who are likely to stay.
Very informative. Good place. 👍👍
Very cool place to learn about history.

Highly recommended. If you come to Hara Castle, please come here too! ! !

The introduction of Christianity, the feudal lord Arima Harunobu, Hideyoshi's ban on Banten, the misgovernment and oppression of the Matsukura father and son, cruel torture and murder, the anger of Shiro Amakusa and the people's uprising, and its tragic outcome. You can even see replicas of items in the collection (photography is prohibited in the Vatican area).

The staff were good at explaining things, and I learned a lot from Yabumi's explanations and Matsukura Katsuie's fate.

The souvenirs were also very original, and the Amakusa Shiro tenugui were also wonderful.

It was rich in content that I could not have learned from history textbooks.
I now understand why the Shimabara Uprising occurred.
It might be good for elementary school students to study history.
There was a TV video on the way, so I think you can understand the history of Shimabara Christians just by watching it.

2023/11
I went to Hara Castle first, but there was no guidance there.
The same goes for Harajo Parking Lot (Harajo Onsen).
So I came here
Free
There will be a video screening
Free bicycle rental available (1 bicycle)

It's a long walk from here to Hara Castle.
Close to the parking lot on the Harajo Onsen side.

interesting museum and eye opener experience to maritime life. i like to watch the maritim vids on the 7th floor. it gives more insight on maritime tasks and duties. most of the area prohibits photography so please check around for the sign.  many things are displayed as photo and its information so maybe for people that are not interesting to history or naval issues, they will tend to get bored easily. my sons love going to museum though, so they still think this trip is enjoyable. and admission is free
from edo period to ww1, ww2 and JMSDF, including lots of models, captured equipments and medals

If your in Sasebo then it may be worth a look at. You can reach it by either walking or by bus from the JR station. It tells a history of the Japanese navy. Be warned that many floors have a no photography rule. The price of admission is free.

Pros:
Free Admission and free parking.
There's a boat driving simulator on the first floor.
Good view from the top floor (7th Floor)

Cons:
Can't take photos indoors

If you're into Japanese modern history, war history and naval history in general, definitely give this museum a go. I went today, 18th November 2023, it wasn't too busy. At the entrance the staff will give you a plastic numbered token, along with a piece of paper outline, what's allowed and not allowed to be done inside. I got the list of rules in Japanese, even though I'm not Japanese (I know enough to converse).

The staff will definitely recommend you to take the elevator up to the 7th floor and walk your way down. The 7th floor gives you a view of the port, with a navy ship in the distance. One of the two places you can take a photo. The other floor is the 1st or 2nd floor. Spent a couple of hours here, it was rather very informative. They also have a LOT of model warships, IJN Kongo, IJN Mikasa, IJN Yamato, IJN Musashi, IJN Tsuzutsuki etc.

A reconstructed Dutch warehouse from 1639. The original was destroyed only a year later as the anno 1639 marker was deemed too Christian. The museum features a lot of cool artifacts, including a suit of European medieval armor, a beautiful imported Indian chair shown to be the same model as that acquired by the Matsura clan. I enjoyed the interactive globe tool that shows the development of the East India Company over time, its colonies and trade posts, ship routes with cargo info; it was my favorite part of the museum. Unfortunately, there is only partial information in English.

Back in the early decades of the Tokugawa shogunate, Roman Catholicism had established itself in Japan's western provinces (Nagasaki, previously a remote fishing village, was de facto founded by the Jesuits in the early 1570s), and was making notable inroads further east in Kansai, too. The first Tokugawa, Ieyasu, averse to the Portuguese and Spanish missionaries, nevertheless maintained cordial relations with the Lutheran Dutch and Protestant English - on the understanding that they would stay in their lane.
Ieyasu's son, Hidetada, and grandson, Iemitsu, had none of the old man's sentiment towards these foreign interlopers, regardless of denomination, and by 1638 foreigners, with their spouses and children, were being driven to Batavia (Jakarta) and elsewhere.
To the building in review; it is a replica of a Dutch factory that was demolished, in the early 1640s in accordance with Iemitsu's "locked country" policy. Around that time the Dutch were shipped out to Dejima, Nagasaki, where they were, to all intents and purposes, incarcerated for almost 250 years.
The building itself is pleasant enough and its museum contains a few artifacts of note; excavated items and those dredged out of the harbour. Here you can learn a very superficial history of the Dutch in Hirado.
Why do I give this only three stars? In my opinion, the museum represents a missed opportunity. In 1613, four years after the Dutch, until bankruptcy a mere ten years later, the English established a trading post lead by cape (head) factor Richard Cocks, and William "Miura Anjin" Adams. The ensuing Anglo-Dutch rivalry, endured by the hapless Cocks and instigated by his Dutch counterpart Jacques Spex, is worthy of a Hollywood trilogy. These capers, a sort of John Le Carre meets Errol Flynn meets Jack Sparrow, as seen through the eyes of a merchant whose bookkeeping was frequently defeated by his own ledger, are noteworthy contributions to the history of Hirado, and yet this narrative is curiously omitted from the museum.
Fortunately for us, Richard Cocks left behind his diary and a collection of letters to read (they are freely available on the internet). So, by all means visit and get your snaps for social media. Then go and read the back story to the Dutch and English traders in Hirado. Trust me, the day-to-day life of a commodities merchant living in early Edo Japan is not as dull as it might sound!

The tour inside will take about 15 minutes. It is very interesting, they show what kind of spices were traded and the trade agreement and other items.
However, if you are not in the close to this area, I would not say it is worth it traveling this far (takes about 4 hours to get here from Nagasaki by bus).
Interesting museum about the 1600s Dutch trading post. I recommend stopping by if you're visiting the nearby Hirado Castle.

It was quite small and not too many things were displayed with a 300yen change. But the lady staff there was really nice. Tho with not a lot of things, the whole displacement and the exhibition were put together quite nicely. Note: they do not have parking space in front of the building.
Not very spectacular. But nice.

[City-designated historic site, Tengo-do, inside the former Chinese mansion]

Tojin Yashiki was created by the Tokugawa Shogunate as part of its national isolation policy.
It is a residence for Chinese people established in the present-day Tateuchi town,
It was completed in the second year of Genroku (1689).

Tengo-do was founded in the first year of Genbun (1736).
People in the Nanjing region pray for safe navigation,
It is said to have its origin as a shrine to St. Mary's Tin Hau.
Renovated in 1790,
It was renovated in 1902 and is still in use today.

[Teen Hau St. Mary]

Mazu, also known as the Virgin Mary of Tin Hau,
In 960 AD during the Northern Song Dynasty of China,
Born into a Hayashi family in a small fishing village on the Fujian coast.
He's a real person.
She didn't cry for a month after she was born.
She was named "Lin Mokuniang".
He has been intelligent since childhood,
At the age of 16, he was guided by God and received a bronze tag with legal power.
It is said that it was given to him.
Then he used his divine powers to travel around the country,
She who wards off evil and disaster and heals people's illnesses.
She is now called the ``Spirit Woman of Tsugen'' with respect.
became.

I finished my training on September 9th, when I was 28 years old.
Even after being called to heaven,
Dancing on the sea wearing a red costume,
I was seen rescuing refugees,
People built shrines to worship the god who protects the country and saves people.
I started to worship it.

These achievements spread throughout the country,
Successive emperors were also referred to as ``Tian Consort'', ``Tian Hau'', and ``Heavenly Virgin''.
We expressed our respect by giving them titles such as:
Mazu is not only a sea god who protects the safety of navigation, but also
natural disasters and epidemics,
As a goddess who protects people from thieves,
In addition to mainland China and Taiwan,
It is believed in many parts of the world where overseas Chinese live.

Tin Hau is another name for Mazu.
The Mazu temple is located in a Chinese mansion, but it seems like not many tourists come here, so it was in disrepair and overgrown with grass.
I came to visit Mazu, so I felt a little disappointed.
I thought it would be better to take care of it a little more, so I put in more donations than usual.
Unlike the Mazu temples at Sofuku-ji and Kofuku-ji, it was great to be able to see and pray to the Mazu statue that is enshrined here quite closely.

Tengo-do is one of the four buildings on the ruins of the Tojin mansion. Fujian Hall also had a Tenhou Hall, but this one seems to have been built by people from Nanjing.

Originally, Tojin Yashiki was an area where Chinese people were imprisoned due to the national isolation policy, and it is said that the main purpose of the internment was to prevent smuggling.

On the other hand, Tianhou Hall is dedicated to Mazu.
Mazu is said to be the god of navigation and safe childbirth, and was widely supported by the people.

When you hear that Tengo-do is a place where people pray for a safe voyage in a Chinese mansion built to prevent smuggling, the word sounds a bit interesting.

By the way, among the four halls, Tenhou Hall is the most atmospheric.
There are fine houses in the vicinity, and it can be said to be a place where cultures are literally mixed, as it is the site of a Chinese-Japanese mansion.

In addition, there was a brick building in front of Tengo-do, and it was a public restroom that looked splendid.
I usually live in Singapore. Compared to the Chinese-style temple there, this one felt unsatisfactory due to its lack of decoration and popularity.

data.name: 長崎街道ここに始まるの石碑

reviews.text: This is the starting point of the old Nagasaki Kaido (Sugar Road).
There is a market here in the morning. After visiting the shrine, you can come and take a walk.

For those looking for amazing views of Nagasaki and the surrounding areas, the Inasayama Ropeway provides an exhilarating and memorable experience. You will be in awe of the magnificence of nature as you ascend Mount Inasa in the cosy confines of the ropeway and take in the expansive views.At the base station, where the adventure starts, hop on the ropeway and get ready for an exciting ride up to the top. You'll experience a growing sensation of expectancy as the gondola softly lifts off the ground and ascends above the city below.The ropeway offers breathtaking vistas that cannot be beat. From the calm waters of Nagasaki Bay to the tall buildings of downtown Nagasaki, every viewpoint presents a different picture of this dynamic metropolis. And as you get higher, the surroundings open up in front of you, displaying verdant woods, undulating hills, and far-off mountains that reach the horizon.Still, there's more to the Inasayama Ropeway journey than just the breathtaking scenery. Savour the feeling of the flight itself as you soar over the skies, suspended at a great height above the earth. Whether you're travelling alone, with friends, or with family, the ropeway offers a special chance to be in touch with the natural environment and recognise its beauty.You can tour viewing decks with 360-degree views of Nagasaki and the surrounding area at the summit. The peak of Mount Inasa provides an amazing view point, whether you visit during the day to see the city drenched in sunlight or at night to see the dazzling lights below.All things considered, the Inasayama Ropeway trip is an experience that visitors to Nagasaki simply must have. You will have lifelong memories from this experience thanks to the breathtaking vistas, smooth ride, and sense of adventure. Thus, take advantage of the opportunity to soar over the city and witness Nagasaki from an entirely different angle.
Riding the Ropeway down Inasayama is an exhilarating experience.

Nice place for visiting.
You have to start from Fuchi Shrine Station.
A quick ride to the top for a great view.

The cable car that comes down from the observation deck on the mountain. After watching the night view, please pay attention to the time and take it quickly. There are two places. One is more popular among Japanese people because it goes to the parking lot in the middle. The other is directly to the bottom of the mountain. I took the elevator and queued down below, and the wait was over half an hour.

Wonderful observatory that is really well maintained. One two levels. Higher level dodges all the trees to allow clear photos. Lower level need to work between them. Be warned! Coming from the tram you make your way up via the long angled elevator then the vertical one, however from here we are talking a lot of stairs and sharply slopped paths. Is a nice walk to get up but your calves and ankles will be tested. There are toilet facilities and some car parks available. Went at night and seemed to have a few couples going together up there. Really nice views of both the city and the bridge. Can be a bit windy so pick the right day.

Very good view point and totally free, unlike the  one on the other side of town. It's not quite as high but you still get views of the ocean and of the town at night. We walked up from near Glover Garden and fair warning, it is quite a lot of stairs. It seemed like there was also a road up there so I'm sure you could get a taxi or drive if you wanted. If walking, you'll need to be moderately fit or able to take your time.

There's toilets at the top too but that's all, no cafe or anything like the other viewpoint. I'd suggest doing Glover Garden, getting a coffee at 丘の上のコーヒー館 耕美庵, which is also nearby and then walking up here for sunset.
Lots of stairs (elevator is also available) but best spot to watch the sunset over Nagasaki.
Nice view, u can climb a little bit more stairs after two elevators from 石橋站. Free in charge and not many travelers to visit.
One of the best views in Nagasaki, but a bit of a hike to get there. I wish there was a vending machine there as well.

I have seen many statues of Sakamoto Ryoma since I came to Japan, from Kyoto to Kochi and now Nagasaki, and I just say this is probably the most difficult to reach if you’re not driving and decided to take the hike, and it’s also the most beautiful and majestic as it overlooks the harbor which once oversaw most of the trade between Japan and the outside world. It was totally worth it and the hike was particularly exciting.

Hopefully I can visit again during the autumn season.
Nice park with a bunch of lookout spots to catch the sun setting over the water.

I never knew we have such a beautiful refreshing venue this close to city! A view tower to view the city, open play grounds and a cozy park where you can hang up rest and relax 🥰 It really felt so good to be there 😊😊

One of my favorite parks to visit for a beautiful view of Nagasaki City! I climbed up via steps through a cemetary off of Shianbashi tram stop and though it’s a workout, it’s worth it. The cherry blossoms are beautiful, a statue of Sakamoto Ryoma can be found here, and there’s a small art museum (free admission).
Peaceful park you can find easter eggs about Sakamoto Ryoma here and along the way when you walk up to this hill.
Nice relaxing place
