There is a large parking lot and toilets, and you can walk through the wetlands by following the boardwalks and information boards at Kurosaki Nagata Wetland Nature Park. Behind the toilets, there were explanations and exhibits about the wetlands, and after looking around for a bit, we walked along the wooden path. There are parts of the wooden path that are rotten, so be careful where you step. As I walked, I could hear the birds singing and the dragonflies flying around, which soothed my soul. thanks
Ren was introduced on the internet news the other day, so I went there right away. My visit was on June 30th, but it looks like I can still enjoy it. The water hyacinth was also very beautiful.

The lotuses were blooming beautifully~
➦It seems like you can observe various plants and insects depending on the season.
Good place to take a break from driving
There are restrooms and tourist information.
➦The lotuses were blooming beautifully ~ It seems that the morning is best ~
It's a good place to take a break from driving.
➦There was a health plaza~
There are also interesting equipment ☆

It is located in an easily accessible location along the national highway. I think the best time to go is from spring to summer when the irises are in bloom. The surrounding area is well maintained, so I think it can be enjoyed as a hiking course. There is also a lively health plaza right next door, so you can do some light exercise.

This is a really beautiful park. Walking in it with the sea breeze and the lively sound of the community is very refreshing and soothing. It wasn’t too hot in the autumn afternoon and you can easily find spots under the tree or benches to sit and chat with your friends. The view from the wharf at different locations in the park is just breathtaking.
Beautiful and romantic seaside park especially during sunset.
This park is huge and has a great vibe. I enjoyed watching the boats go by and enjoying the Nagasaki views. There is toilets and drinks machines.

The cool breeze of the sea and the warm ambience of the park ask me to be there time and again! So this mind freshening spot has become my best place to visit every week!! Be sure the place will keep haunting you once you visit there ❤️❤️

It's a very beautiful and breathtaking scenery, especially in the early morning as the sun is raising. You can hear all the bells ringing in harmony, the birds are singing, and the music of a new day start to play.
I love this place, I want to visit again.

data.formatted_address: Ogushigo, Kawatana, Higashisonogi District, Nagasaki 859-3618, Japan
data.name: Osaki Peacock Nature Park

reviews.text: Not busy and large howlings of Peacocks. Good place for time killing.

it's pretty ok. It has peacock's, flamingos, horses,goats, bumper cars, motor cart track (which was closed when we went), garden, nice nature trail with views, and a nice park. It is free to get Into, just have to pay to do the bumper cars, feed the animals, or the motor cart. Overall tho it is still a nice pass time for the kids with the park. The park has no shade so be sure to dress appropriate. Have water and a fan so you dont overheat.

Peacock Park and Wild Fowl Refuge.  Free to get in.  Peacocks, flamingos, ponies, and some other animals are kept here.  A trail head from the back of the building by the parking lot will lead you down the mountain and to a paved path that goes by the water.  Just watch for wild boars.
Animals need to be taken care of more.
Very nice free park with a simple hiking path. The animals seem to be in very good health and happy.
One of the most relaxing parks
A large park with a beach and a campground adjacent to it. I used it for a toilet break.
I stopped for a toilet break. It's a quiet and well-maintained park where you can enjoy Kawahara Oike, and I think it's a good place to take your pet for a walk or have a light picnic.

It is a campsite with a campsite, kitchen, restrooms, and walking path. There are no convenience stores or shops nearby, so bring what you need! Take your garbage home!
There is one bus per hour.
When you climb up to the observation deck, the view is quite spectacular. Looks good for relaxing and basking in the sun. Cats were gathering.

This campsite has free plots, but you must apply to the Sanwa Administration Center before using it.
Applications can be made by fax after phone call, or by visiting the office.

I'm glad you can bring your pet with you.

IF YOU ARE NEARBY, THIS IS MUST!

Amazing experience. I would suggest to arrive as soon as you can, around 16 o'clock animals are getting ready to go home and sleep (official closing time is 17:00, but actually it starts around 16:15 - different animals go home at different times). Also some animals you can feed only before a certain hour such as monkeys (11:00 to 15:00). And for some other animals vegetables/ other food may be sold out already due to the limited amount. Sooner is better there, I wish we would know that in advance.

You will spend 2 hours there minimum, I would suggest to plan with 3-4h, 4h would be ideal. Also take a lot of 100yen coins, you would need them for purchasing food for animals - 10-15x 100y coins for a person would be ideal.

You can touch a lot of animals here - at your own risk, but they are calm (and feed them). Such as flamingos, capybaras, kangaroos, monkeys, lemurs and racoons (you can touch just their paws while feeding them).

It's really a unique experience. Animals there are well cared for, clean, happy.

I would rather support this amazing place than some cafe where animals have never seen dirt before.

One tip: If you feel like it you can feed the animals from your hand. Put your fingers together and open your hand fully. Then place the treat in middle of your palm. Show it to the capybara, kangaroo or flamingo and let them eat it from your hand.

I went here on a Saturday morning from Huis Ten Bosch. There is a free shuttle from Huis Ten Bosch to Nagasaki Biopark but you need to reserve in advance.

We availed the biopark + PAW ticket. If you are not afraid of or allergic to animals, I recommend purchasing the combo ticket. PAW was such a fun experience. You can pet inus (dogs), nekos (cats), guinea pigs, goats, rabbits, and squirrel monkeys! The staff was also very cheerful - you can feel how much they care for the animals.

It was different from the other zoos because you can actually see the animals up close, interact with them and feed them. You have to prepare a lot of coins. The highlight for me would be the capybara zone. They were sleeping when we arrived so we went back. I also enjoyed the raccoons (lol). They were super cute. And lastly Momo the hippo. She was sleeping when we arrived. We waited for a while until she woke up. You can feed her cabbage and this will make her happy. We wanted to stay a bit longer to see her feeding time but it was quite late in the afternoon. Hope to come back when there are more events / activities - capybara bath,  etc.

The kids seem to enjoy so much - I think when I have kids someday I will definitely bring them here too 😊

Went on a Friday afternoon, and the park was not busy at all. This is a very unique zoo; animals have plenty of room to roam around and they seem happy! The interactions you get with some of the animals here makes the experience interesting and to an extent, justifies 1900¥ per person. I have never been this close this many zoo animals. However, the park needs to provide a higher quality of food at the exhibits. Only 4 to 5 small pieces to feed after paying yet another fee ranging from 100¥-500¥ is ridiculous. Also, I would not do the extra 600¥ to see the dogs and cats. Way too many children crowding a small space and the animals didn't see too happy to be surrounded by so many people. Otherwise, it's worth the visit if you're in the area!

Truly a zoo nested in a natural hillside environment unlike those found in the bigger cities. The entrance dome felt like i was entering a lost civilisation.

Plenty of opportunity to interact n feed the animals. Numerous encounters with crabs that roam freely along the paths through the park.

I really liked my visit, we had a great time and there’s a lot to see. A lot of the animals enclosures were closed and some of them don’t have enough space to be so they look a little sad. The ones where you can feed them and interact with them seem a lot happier. Be prepared with a lot of 100 yen coins for all the feeding.
It's a free mini zoo. The bird enclosures are a bit too small though, don't look very comfortable for the birds

Look this place is not an Australian zoo with natural inspired habitats etc, it is small and old school with only a dozen small animals. Free to get in, and you pay to feed some of the animals.
Entry gate is hard to find, ended up well above it, and the climb up to the temple is extreme.
The cages were tiny and the badger looked like it had gone crazy after being cooped up for so long. The animals didn't look clean or happy. A nice place to feel depressed.

Free to enter.
But didn’t seem kept up well.
You can feed the animals, but only through small tubes…
Small but nice zoo where you can feed goats, monkeys and the like.

data.formatted_address: Huis Ten Bosch Machi, Sasebo, Nagasaki 859-3243, Japan
data.name: Waterfall of Light

reviews.text:
The display of files here is very beautiful. But you have to stay overnight here because the last train leaves at 8:00 p.m. The light show starts around 8:00 p.m. onwards.
Stay here, you won't be disappointed 😊😊
Because it is so beautiful, I recommend that everyone in Huis Ten Bosch stay until night and come to this place to see the beautiful waterfalls.

Colorful pictures taken from a distance
Super spectacular!
Recommended to visit at night

An illumination show projected onto the Domtorun building in Tower City.
This is a light video show that is linked to each season.
You can enjoy the seasonal world reflected in the waterfall of light.
The vast scenery flowing from the night sky to the art garden is breathtaking.
The view from the Art Garden Observation Deck is the best!

The beauty of the waterfall of light seen from the art garden is amazing!
You can also see the light display from the garden pool.

From an Americans perspective, it's a cute little park. Centered around children. But it's a nice hike if you're looking for an uphill hike with some nice views for pictures. The actual park wasn't that great but the hike up to it is beautiful.

This place is awesome to go with children! I like how everything here makes children be active, unlike place like Disneyland where the rides are passive experiences. There is a huge 3d structure made from ropes to climb around in, very complex. Trampolines, playhouse… a „Pool“ of wooden balls… lots of space to run! A safe place. If you have a child and are in Nagasaki this is one of her best places by far.
Such an amazing theme park you can enter for free! Flowers are very well-maintained, and everything was so organized! I highly recommend to watch the sunset from the top of the hill there.
Great place to have fun with the children
Nice Place to spend time with kids

data.formatted_address: Huis Ten Bosch Machi, Sasebo, Nagasaki 859-3243, Japan
data.name: VR World

reviews.text: Kids friendly. No gravity force from actual roller coasters. Video quality is bad as well.

Premium Ticket ~ Royal 6, Quick Pass eligible facility.
VR-KING was disappointing, so I had low expectations, but I enjoyed this one!

reverse bungee
At first, it was really scary and I thought VR was really amazing, but I was disappointed because the moment I fell, I didn't feel like I was floating.

The one going down the river
This was more powerful and interesting than the reverse bungee! It was an attraction that made me want to ride it even more.

Even in the VR world of Huis Ten Bosch, the Ultra Reverse Bungee is in a class of its own 👍. I was also able to get priority boarding on VR King with my standard 3 premium ticket, but Ultra Reverse Bungy was better in terms of content. If you have time, we also recommend white water rafting. For that, you will need premium6 instead of standard3 premium ticket. If you have more than two days, you can use standard 3 for two days. Premium6 might be good if you come in first thing in the morning and stay until closing. It's also perfect for taking a break.

R4.12.5
Enter around 11:30

The photo was taken at 11:50, but the actual time in line was probably about half the time.

The ride time is about 5 minutes? I wonder what goggles are, they take a long time to put on.
Besides, I had almost no sense of reality (bitter smile).
I read in the reviews that there are quite a few lines, but I wonder if it varies depending on the day because it's a school trip or something?
I thought there would be less waiting time in the evening, so I asked the staff and they told me that there would be about 1,000 people on a school trip in the afternoon, so I visited all three main locations around noon.

Site of the foreigners only area in Nagasaki (and Japan) until the opening up of the country in the 19th century.

Built to the period of the 17th and 18th Century with buildings further down built during the Meiji era.

Contains a gift shop and cafe. Displays have English and Japanese descriptions.

A must see in Nagasaki. Great site with tons of information in English.
The care taken in rebuilding with the original method is exceptional.

Give yourself a lot of time to explore this little gem.
This was the residence of the deputy head of Dejima. The first floor is now a museum shop (business hrs: 9 - 18).
Really interesting to learn about the history of early foreigners in Japan! Definitely worth a visit!

We visited the former Portuguese and then Dutch settlement in Nagasaki. The site was very informative with plenty of great interactive exhibits. We especially enjoyed the narrative of the hidden Christians in Nagasaki.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒850-0862 Nagasaki, Dejimamachi, 1−１ 長崎出島ワーフ 2階 国際観光コンベンション協会内
data.name: 長崎遊学券

reviews.text: Recommended by many people

The marketplace inside the station (which has dozens of stores selling castella cakes, Japanese confectionery, food products and souvenirs) is an ideal place for last-minute gift shopping before boarding the train.

During my trip to Nagasaki, I stopped by to buy souvenirs.
Although there were quite a few customers probably because it was a weekday.
Some shops were a bit strange, with staff chatting with each other.
Of course, the person at the store who helped me was very nice.
I think it's better to be aware that people are watching you even when you have free time.
Also, it's not as big as I thought.
It's easy to get lost in the rows of souvenir shops in Sapporo's underground shopping mall, but this is probably due to the difference in the number of tourists visiting.
I bought some hatoshi here and ate it, and it was delicious.
The lady at the shop spoke the local language and I felt like I was in Nagasaki.
I think everyone could use a little more dialect to respond.
This is true of any tourist destination.

In Nagasaki's once-in-a-century period of transformation, a project to improve the area around Nagasaki Station has been promoted in order to improve the number of people moving out, which is the worst for two years in a row. The old Nagasaki station building, which had a triangular roof with a large German-style round clock and stained glass, ended its role, and with the opening of the Nishi-Kyushu Shinkansen, a new 13-story station building was built to attract a luxury hotel, the Marionette Hotel. Kamome Market held its grand opening on March 18, 2022. Located on the first floor of the station, it has one of the largest souvenir zones in Nagasaki city and a total of 56 restaurants. There is also Kamome Yokocho, where you can enjoy local sake. When I go on a trip, I buy souvenirs for my relatives and friends at this souvenir shop. A staple in our house is Fukusaya's castella. I sometimes buy Cruz's Omagari Neko can and Amu's Senjuan's Nyastera from this souvenir shop for my cat-loving friends. The Family Mart in the station has ekiben, and we recommend the Kakuni Meshi from Sakamotoya, which won second place in the 2023 Kyushu Ekiben Grand Prix. I would like to go eat at Uo Asa which has good reviews on Google Maps soon.

In front of the Nagasaki Station ticket gate. We have a complete selection of Nagasaki's famous sweets, specialty products, and souvenirs. Kawakami Bundando from Sasebo was in attendance at the event space, and they told me that their zabon pickles are grown from zabon, and the taste is exquisite.

September 2023: Delicious food from Nagasaki was gathered at the station building at Nagasaki Station. There are souvenir shops, restaurants, and bars, and I used it many times since I was staying near the station for several nights.
However, since the surrounding area was unfinished, it was a hassle to take a detour from Amu Plaza to the construction site.
very clean market and the restaurant for breakfast is good
This is a market that sells fresh fish from Nagasaki. Although it is usually not open to the public, it is open to the public during the fish festival.

fresh fish is sold
Is the toilet a bit dirty?

I definitely go every year. Although the sale of fresh fish was canceled due to the coronavirus, there were many other events going on, and I bought dried fish and kamaboko, which were absolutely delicious.
It's a very interesting market with fish that you can't find in supermarkets.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒850-0057 Nagasaki, Daikokumachi, 3−１ 長崎交通産業ビル
data.name: Nagasaki Traditional Gifts & Souvenirs Shop

reviews.text: nice place over there
Great gifts and local souvenirs!

A completely different selection of pottery and other items from the airport. Lots of local sauces and ponzu sauce too! I was so impressed that they even sold dried horse mackerel! It also helps that it opens at 9am.

There are a variety of souvenirs on the second floor of the express bus in front of Nagasaki Station, which I don't think is a bad thing, but there are few people and it's dark, so it's hard to feel like buying, and most people shop at Nagasaki Station. It seems that

It seems like they have everything, but the souvenir I wanted to buy wasn't here.
Perhaps because it was a weekday, I was the only customer, so it felt like an old-fashioned souvenir shop with a staff member.
If you're flying home, it's probably better to buy at the airport.
When the Shinkansen opens, Kamome Market will be cleaner and easier to see, so the necessity of having an old souvenir shop here may disappear.

If you have a one-day tram ticket, there is a discount.

Only the fish shop was open.
There is a bazaar in the back where you can buy a variety of cheap things at the flea market. It is one of the few survivors of the Nagasaki market, which until recently was plentiful and vibrant. There were photos and paintings from when it was a bustling market, and I thought it would be great if the market could be as lively as it is again.

Currently, there are only fish shops (retail) and the same (wholesale).
I miss you so much.
Where is the bustle of the past?

it is the park as the remembrance of the atomic blast in year 1945. the location is up on higher land but luckily there are long escalators set that bring us up. along the walk, we can see fountain of peace and peace bell. the main spot of this place is a big statue at the end of the path. it's right hand that point up to the sky is to remind about the past atomic bomb and the left is to symbolize peace.
A Nagasaki landmark. A must visit when in Nagasaki. Beautiful monument. A marker on the right corner give the narrative of the sculpture.

The statue's raised right hand pointing to the sky symbolizes the threat of nuclear weapons; his flat outstretched left hand represents eternal peace; and his eyes are closed in prayer, asking that the souls of the victims may find rest.

The Mog Champ sends his regards.

The Peace Statue has a nice and cool pose! Of course this statue also has a strong symbolic significance to not only the people of Japan but for those around the world as well. Pay your respects and have a nice photo for the memories.

Mogliest Regards,
Your Mog Champ

The Peace Statue in Nagasaki symbolizes the city's wish for a peaceful world without nuclear weapons. Located in the Peace Park, this 10-meter tall statue's raised right hand points to the threat of nuclear war while the left arm stretches out in a gesture of peace. Erected in 1955, it stands as a solemn reminder of the atomic bombing of Nagasaki in 1945 and the city's enduring hope for global peace.

The fountain of peace is dedicated as a water offering to the spirits of the atomic bomb victims, thousands of whom suffered terrible burns and died scrambling for a drink of water.

The water spray from the fountain is shaped like a pair of wings, evoking images of the peace dove and the crane,  the symbol of Nagasaki Harbor which is also known as Crane Harbor.
it is a fountain as part of the peace park
Memory to remember
Beautiful fountain with a beautiful message.
next stop after Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum. bring umbrella or wear a cap in case you want to stay or walk around.
A nice place to visit and just take in the space. Nothing much to see, but it is a good reminder that an atomic bomb was used here in Nagasaki.
Need to visit if in the area. Take a minute to silence for the lost souls. The devlopment of the area doesn't seem like there was boom dropped back then

Small park near the atomic bomb museum where the atomic bomb was dropped. There is a tremendous weight and purpose just standing at the hypocentre given the implications and scale of destruction that was unleashed upon the very spot years ago. Worth a visit in Nagasaki and to remember the tragic events the unfolded.
The black granite monolith marks the hypocenter of the atomic bomb explosion. It was erected in 1956 to enshrine the names of those who died in the blast.
There are some kind people here, and they even have A4 size picture frames. Moreover, there is a considerable repertoire. There aren't many picture frame stores in Nagasaki, so it's a big help.

I'm worried about something,
solved.
I appreciate it very much.
They will kindly explain and respond to you.

data.name: アンティークマヨリカ

reviews.text: I came here for the first time in about 20 years. This is the store where I used to buy Venetian glass earrings with my mother, and when I went there with nostalgic memories, I found the store to be very nostalgic. The owner of the shop also answered my questions about the products and explained them in detail, and even showed me some Venetian glass beads. I would like to visit you again.
You can purchase antique items.

data.name: PW/GALLERY(ピーダブリューギャラリー)
長崎の猫雑貨 nagasaki-no neco

reviews.text: cute little shop filled with cat (and nagasaki cats) goods. Store owner is friendly.
Super cute stuff!! Rly recommend
There are shops selling Omagari Neko, a cat with a curved tail, as well as miscellaneous goods and stationery. I bought a postcard~

This is a cat goods store.
Each miscellaneous goods had its own personality and there were some cute items.
The store staff was easy to talk to and carefully introduced the products.
I wanted to go again.
There is no parking space, so we recommend parking at a nearby parking lot.
The interior was cute, and it looked like a shrine dedicated to cats, and instead of offering money, there was a fish-shaped wooden object, and being surrounded by cats was very soothing!

Onkodo is a wonderful treasure in the rough. My favorite kind of place to search for antiques and there are many here! The owner is nice man but his shop is unorganized. There is plenty of see and buy. You name it he's got it! Seriously a treasure trove of real good antiques.

The store is cluttered. The condition of the item is not good, but the price is high. It depends on the item, but it was twice the market price on Yahoo! Auctions. If you are going to buy it here, I think it would be better to wait for it to be listed on Yahoo! Auctions.
very good. wonderful

data.name: ちいさなギャラリー&工房

reviews.text:
A stylish cafe with a calm atmosphere.
There is a gallery upstairs where you can enjoy art.
Both drinks and desserts were delicious 😊

The owner happened to come by and we had a nice chat.
thank you.

I used it for the first time♪
It seemed like a recently opened shop, so there was a cafe on the first floor and a gallery on the second floor that you could tour.
I ordered a chocolate bar and hand drip coffee!
The older sister was running the business by herself and seemed like a nice person with a smile on her face.
The atmosphere inside the store was nice and stylish (^^)
I still want to use it! ️

The first floor is a stylish cafe♡
There are wonderful exhibits on the second floor and rooftop! !

The staff are also nice and it's easy to go even by yourself ( ˶`﹀´˵ )
The chocolate bar is so delicious ⡱੭𖠚 ⡱

Cafe latte ¥600 and chocolate bar ¥650 🍫

Here is chocolate_bar2017 in Takamiya, Fukuoka.
You can eat chocolate cake🥰

There was nothing like that written on the menu.
I think there are many people who don't know 😍

While I was waiting for my order, I climbed the spiral staircase to the 2nd and 3rd floor.
I went to see the paintings ^^
By the way, photography of each painting is prohibited!

I had a delicious chocolate cake in a relaxing space 🥰
Since there is no one-drink system, just the chocolate cake was OK!
By the way, there was also cold food☺️

Please go and try it🥰

At first I thought that this was a digital museum, perhaps related to robots, but apparently not. Gunkanjima itself is a small island that used to have coal mines. At that time, the population on this island was so dense that island development actually reached the shores of the island. So if you look at it, this island looks like a warship. Currently this island is uninhabited and the buildings on this island are dangerous because they could collapse. This island also has been used for shooting several movies. This Gunkanjima digital museum tells the history of this island in digital form, with interesting photos and digital media, apart from that there is also VR which makes us really feel like we are on the island and explore the island, including its ruins.

Joined a local tour to Gunkanjima and gather here to spend around an hour to visit the museum before hopping onto the cruise. The museum is great yet no English for most of the content. Would definitely have a better experience if you get to know about the history before stepping on Gunkanjima island.

This digital museum brings to life the ruins of Gunkanjima by utilizing projection mapping, VR, videos and interactive displays. A collage of thousands of photos shown on a 30-meter wide screen gives visitors a glimpse of the residents' every day life before the island was abandoned. The virtual trip down the mine shaft to the undersea coal mining site in a cage and a trolley is an eye-opening experience.

The museum shop is stocked with nifty souvenirs. I bought a 1/4000 scale Gunkanjima diorama model, a metal keychain and a small lump of Hashima coal.

Stand-alone tickets are expensive (JP¥ 1,800). However, admission is free for those who have booked the Gunkanjima Concierge Landing Tour.

Well designed and nicely executed museum. For those who are not totally infatuated with Gunkanjima in the first place, I wonder if it's totally worth the 1800 yen entrance fee. There are some nice interactive displays in several languages, explanations are mostly available in English, only the narrations on the big screen are in Japanese only. Many videos with Interview of former inhabitants available. You could spend a lot of time here if you wanna go all in.

great museum. very well-planned and offers many interesting exhibits that rely on the use of technology, like VR to bring you around the parts of the island with restricted access. staff are very helpful as well.
however, those driving please note that are a some unscrupulous people running a scam parking lot just outside, so be careful of where you park. strongly suggest that the museum stations one staff member outside the museum during peak periods (right before the tours) to direct cars to the proper parking lot.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒850-0901 Nagasaki, Motoshikkuimachi, 2, ２−１９ ナンコンピザ ２ 階
data.name: 風のアタゴオル
Kujukushima Zoo & Botanical Gardens Mori Kirara

reviews.text:
I’ve been visiting our neighborhood zoo since my daughter was six months old, and now that she’s two, she loves it even more! The zoo is within walking distance for us, making it a perfect place for frequent visits. The staff are incredibly helpful and kind, always enhancing our experience.

We have an annual pass and this zoo is a fantastic spot to spend one to two hours with family, enjoying a diverse range of animals. The garden is a delightful bonus, with beautiful seasonal flowers and plants that add to the charm of the place. We always leave with smiles and look forward to our next visit!

I’ve lived here over 4 years and this is the first time I’ve actually visited for leisure. The first time I came I only went as far as the giraffes near the front for a volunteer event.

This is a pretty decently sized zoo to visit especially with little ones. I love the way their penguin exhibit is set up and apparently there’s a sort of cafe or seating area that we missed. For 2 adults with a military discount it was literally around ¥1200! For an annual pass it’s ¥2100! For our son’s first visit to a zoo this was the perfect size and as soon as we were done he fell right asleep. Parking is free and just right across the street.

There is a diaper changing room in the penguin exhibit building as well as a men’s and women’s restroom. The bathroom was very clean.

We used to live in Sasebo 5 yrs ago and had never been to this zoo until the other day. It’s super cute, but as it was soooo hot out, we didn’t see many animals. My kids and I still made the most of it. If you’re in Sasebo, check it out. It doesn’t receive the same attention as Biopark, but it is amazing and close to Kujukushima aquarium.

Happy to have a place to take our child to learn about animals.  They try really hard here to provide a good experience. Like most things in japan the property is quite dated.  Lots of bathrooms available. For the price it is a great way to spend an hour. Purely on the condition of the property, it's 3 stars.

We had a great time!  The zoo and aquarium are small but the animals were beautiful and fascinating.  The staff was very friendly and informative about the animals.  Also there is a flower hothouse to visit.

Our children loved this small penguin focused aquarium.  You can get there by bus or taxi-- taxi is about 3,800 yen.  It's a 200m walk from the roads to the aquarium.  The penguins also have a private beach that they are free to walk on and swim at! How cool is that!?!

Honestly worth the bus ride all the way from main area of Nagasaki, it was such a beautiful mountainous area too. The penguin aquarium was worth it, and the little penguins are so cute! They have the most species out of any aquarium in Japan, and I think most countries as well.
It was a nice experience in Nagasaki Penguin Aquarium. The sea view was eye soothing. You can use Nagasaki Bus Service. 320 yen is the regular bus fare from Nagasaki Station.

They claim to be the place with the most types of penguins (9 out of 18 types). Pretty fun and modest place to spend some time on. It is not large, with just a few large areas for penguins and other aquatic creatures scattered around here and there. But it is not expensive and not too hard to access by bus. This might be heaven for penguin lovers, for others it’s still nice to spend an hour or so here.

Best place ever. Home to 9 (out of 18 total) different penguin species whereas most aquariums only have 1-2 types. The feeding times (at 11am or 3pm) are cuteness overload with penguins frantically waddling after food. The museum also has a ton of information about all the penguin species and very nice visuals. We spent over 3 hours at the aquarium without getting bored.
Beautiful place

Nagasaki Park spreads out next to Osuwa-san.
The small zoo is free.
It's a short walking course.
There is also Tsukimi Chaya, which is famous for its udon and botamochi.

I was surprised at how large Nagasaki Park is.
There are many stone monuments, statues, and monuments, so there is plenty to see.
I went to Suwa Shrine for New Year's visit. We also saw some animals, including goats and monkeys. There were carp in the fountain and pond. the animals were cute
It's a park that both adults and children can enjoy, including Suwa Shrine and an animal plaza.

data.name: Great camphor Tree At Daitoku-ji Temple

reviews.text:
Great presence! Estimated to be 800 years old!
I am overwhelmed by the vitality. The root and trunk are so thick that the entire angle of view cannot fit them.
I wonder what it looked like when the cut branches were there.
If you like Laputa or Ta Prohm at Angkor Wat, you should stop by.
When I went up the torii gate next to me, I saw a cat sleeping comfortably.

It was a wonderful, thick tree. Go up the stairs. Google Maps shows the road below, so look up and see.
Be sure to visit the Umegaya Mochi shop next door from 10:00 to 16:00. Are you closed on Tuesday? It's my first time to have such a big plump plum cake.
This is a large camphor tree that is over 800 years old. It is located on the outskirts of Daitokuji Park. There is also a specialty shop nearby that sells Umegaeda mochi.

Its presence is overwhelming when you stand in front of it. With a trunk circumference of 12.60 meters, this gigantic tree is one of the largest in the prefecture and has been popularly known as the "Daitokuji Kusu" for a long time. The age of the tree is estimated to be around 800 years.
This is a splendid large soup located in the Seven Wonders of Nagasaki, ``Daitokuji Temple, even though there is no temple.''

I visit Fuchi Shrine every now and then, and before I knew it, I saw a sign saying ``Fuchi Shrine camphor tree.''
I see, it is a splendid camphor tree.

Nestled amidst the undulating embrace of ancient, mountainous sentinels, there lies a park, a verdant realm of tranquility and natural splendor. This hallowed ground, woven with a tapestry of slopes and stairways, ascends through the mists of time, an emerald jewel cradled in the earth's bosom.It is here, under the ever-watchful gaze of towering peaks, that the cherry blossoms unfurl their delicate petals, a fleeting symphony of pink and white, heralding the arrival of spring in a spectacle that captivates the hearts of the Japanese people. This sacred rite of nature transforms the park into a canvas of ethereal beauty, a place of contemplation and celebration where families and friends gather in joyous reverence. The verdure of this enchanted haven also plays host to picnics under the dappled shade, where laughter and conversation blend harmoniously with the gentle rustling of leaves. It is a sanctuary for the young, their gleeful shouts echoing through the air as they explore the playground of their imaginations amidst nature's bounty. Adding to its allure, the park boasts a parking area, a modern-day convenience seamlessly integrated into the landscape, ensuring that this hidden paradise remains accessible to all seekers of serenity. From vantage points dotted around, one is treated to a panoramic spectacle – a fantastic view that stretches beyond the horizon, offering a glimpse into the sublime majesty of the universe.Thus, this park, a green haven amidst the mountains, stands not only as a testament to the beauty of the natural world but also as a beacon of peace, a place where the soul can dance in harmony with the rhythms of the earth.
Wonderful place for Hanami (cherry trees flower seeing) in spring in Japan.
If you're lucky enough to be here when the cherry trees are blossoming it is absolutely worth the hike if you're on foot. At other times the views are very nice but other hilltops are better.
Beautiful park especially during cherry blossom season!

Great park up in the hills of Eastern Nagasaki. You have great views of town, other hills, and in my case cherry blossoms. I happened to be in town for the cherry blossom festival so it was beautiful. Some good fair-type of food, think things on a stick, and nice weather.  Worth the trip. I started my trip from the Shianbashi neighborhood and hiked the hill. If you want a good hike do that. Just make sure to go through the park rather than follow the narrow road with the trees in the middle the entire way. You put yourself and drivers at risk. Less adventurous souls can opt for a bus ride or a taxi.

data.name: Mt. Kokuzo Kiba trailhead

reviews.text: There are two trails I think on this mountain, one easy and one more difficult. The view from the top is very beautiful, there is a small shrine at the top too. The hike takes about one hour to the top on the easier trail. Would recommend it! Not too far if you are coming from Sasebo. You do need a car to get here it's not walking distance from the train station.

For some reason, 5G radio waves are coming in (lol)

The road has been widened for parking for climbers.
If we give way, I think we can park about 10 cars.

From around the last village below the trailhead (Kokuzo no Mizu), the slope is so steep that you have to go up in low gear.
There is a restroom just below the trailhead.

The road leading up to the trailhead was so scary 💦 It was narrow and not paved 🥺
The parking space was large, and since we went early in the morning, it was reserved for us ✨️
It had been raining the day before, so I thought I'd be more worried about climbing and returning, but as expected, I slipped once and almost slipped a few times (lol) There were quite a few moss-covered stones and rocks. there is!

Since I was alone, I chose the family course, but there was a zone with ropes and chains just before the top, so I was glad I chose the family course. Next time I would like to try the adventure course ✨️

Is it possible to park about 10 cars? There is another trailhead where you can park, the Iwaya trailhead, but I think there were only 2-3 cars there. Both have toilets. It's about 900 meters from here to the summit, and the first part is a climb through a cedar forest, with a separation between the family course and the adventure course.

The path is not paved, and although there are some stairs, most of the paths have tree roots sticking out of the soil. You can't go there with regular athletic shoes, but trekking shoes are best. I think it will take a little over 40 minutes to reach the top of the mountain. The trail is divided into the ``New Road'', which has a steep road, and the ``Family Course'' (I chose the ``Family Course''). There are two places where you have to climb up using your hands, and three places where you have to pass ropes or chains. I climbed in the season when the temperature was around 20℃, but I was sweating. I think you should bring your own drinks.
The view from the top of the mountain is quite nice 🙆🙆🙆

Amazing for sunset but it's hard to get there. It took me 40 min to get to the top of mountain.
More looks like forest,  not like park. Very peaceful and quiet .
You can see all Nagasaki from there!)
Beware of spiders,  there're s lot of it everywhere

Only a short walk from Nagasaki city centre, you get to see some wilderness and a good workout. Apparently you need to watch out for wild boars, not that I saw any. Good if you want to get out of the crowd for a while. No wheel chair or buggy access.
very nice walking through the woods, via the shrines to the top of the mountain
It's difficult to get to, but it's a beautiful temple with some lovely views.
Good place for an short easy hike. The view of Nagasaki city from the top is nice. Family friendly place.

Very beautiful national forest. We stayed in a log cabin overnight and rented a BBQ. The staff were really helpful and friendly. We walked around part of the forest the next day. The whole site is huge you could spend ages here.

I went there for the first time last Sunday with my kids.
There are various places within the vast grounds.
There is also a campsite 🏕, so I thought it would be good for families to play in the river, catch bugs, and do a lot of other things.

However, if the areas that are not maintained are really not maintained and are managed by the prefecture or city, then I would like the areas listed on the map to be maintained so that they can be accessed safely.

It was disappointing to see that while places that everyone often goes to are maintained, there is a noticeable difference in the management of places that people don't seem to go to very often.

The weather was nice and I went out for a drive for the first time in a while and had some fun with athletics.
I had a nice walk.
However, I was disappointed that the benches placed along the promenade had mold growing on them and didn't seem to have been taken care of.

I will go to the river with my children.
It's in the mountains, so it's cold in the winter, but it's very pleasant in the summer.
You can also catch fish.
Chains will be placed at the entrance to the parking lot at 5pm, so I wish I could play for a little longer.
postscript)
Athletic play equipment has been updated.
Unfortunately the sky was cloudy, but the cherry blossom festival was still being held. There were a lot of kitchen cars and it looked delicious (*^^*)

Supposedly one of the best night views in Japan. Unfortunately, it was the rainy season and there was no view whatsoever when we were at the peak. You can take a cable car to the peak or walk around 500m from the nearest bus station. The park is well maintained and I can only imagine the remarkable views on a clear day.

Having travelled to many places, the night view here can be considered world class. Very peaceful surroundings and not very touristy as compared to Hong Kong or Shanghai. Fairly assesible by bus from Nagasaki Station. Drop at the bus stop before the ropeway station (Ropeway Eki Mae)

The city view is amazing from this spot, can actually even spot local viewpoints from up there! Just be highly aware that if you’re in the majority taking the Nagasaki rope way back down, be prepared for a LONG LONG line to go back down
📍🇯🇵One of Japan’s Best Night Views in Nagasaki: Mount Inasa Observatory

Just great city views. It was simply great to take the cable car up Mt. Inasa in the evening and take photos of Nagasaki at night.

I would love to have seen these views at sunset and during the day, but maybe another time - after all Nakasaki was my co-favourite city in Japan, with Tokyo. It was pretty cold up there in the evening!

Great View! Night scene was gorgeous and beautiful!

There is a Free Shuttle Bus goes around 5 hotels in the city center and one of the bus stop is at Nagasaki Station Bus Stop (East Exit at Traffic Square) and operates a round trip to Nagasaki Ropeway.

**(Everyone can use it, but need to make a Reservation before boarding) You can make a booking online:

https://reserve.nagasaki-ropeway.jp

This is the easiest way to get to the Ropeway Station (Fuchi-Jinjia Station) and return. It’s totally free!

Access to the Inasayama by Ropeway, that’s ¥1250 per Adult.

There was a nice shrine when I went there but sadly was closed when I went (5:45pm)

They have a bunch of omiyage and I bought myself this castella icecream cake for 350¥. It was really really good!

Good view to see nagasaki from.
The staff are very professional and nice in the ropeway.

It's a small but lovely shrine close to the roapway to observatory.
Nicely designed
Beautiful flowers
Very relaxing and silent
Toilets available

I would give it -1 star if I can.
I took their  free shuttle bus that pick up people from hotels. The free shuttle schedule force you to do all the visiting within 1 hour, which is physically impossible. The waiting time to take the ropeway was about 20-40 mins in each leg.
The shuttle bus driver and staff at their parking lot were rude and not helpful. I missed the first bus (because of their ridiculous waiting time). I asked the driver at around 9 pm politely what time the bus would leave, is it 9:30? (in Japanese), and he shouted “I don’t know, if you’re in a hurry, get out now. After kept things vague for so long… the bus left at 9:30 🤷‍♀️
The view from the top was decent, but it’s not in my top 5 list of the best night views. Considering the efforts I put, I think it’s not worths it.

A very secluded beautiful waterfall. Would be great when hot outside to frolic in the water and stream. Wish you needed to hike here, but parking gets you very close. The tunnel is quite creepy and is said to be haunted. When walking through it back to our car, the automatic lights werent turning on until a dog off its leash came running through the opposite directed and scared us half to death!

Up in the wooded mountains of Saikai, you can find Tsugane Otoshi no Taki, a beautiful waterfall and pond hidden at the end of a forest trail. It's a very beautiful area, with the Sound Museum close by! It's a short and easy walk from the parking area to the pond, so you can access it very easily. During the summer months the pond is warm enough to go swimming in.
Quiet waterfall. We didn’t see any other people around when we went. You could get in the water if you wanted to, but it’s pretty cold.

I have often visited this secluded falls by bicycle, motorbike or truck, but never before during the winter. Our recent and rare heavy snowfall convinced me to brave snowy road conditions, and I'm glad I did.
Gorgeous waterfall - look up your route ahead of time as google may take you to a wrong side of the falls.

data.formatted_address: Tsuganeotoshino Falls, Osetocho Yukinouragotsugo, Saikai, Nagasaki 857-2323, Japan
data.name: Tsuganeotoshino Falls

reviews.text: Tsugane Otoshi Falls, located in the northwestern part of Kenmin no Mori, in the lower reaches of Iwasedo Valley, is about 20 meters high, surrounded by deep mountains on both sides, and covered with large rocks, and the water bends as it flows down the huge rocks. I am. This waterfall is famous for its lack of a basin, and the water cascades onto large flat stones at the bottom, creating a truly spectacular splash.

Summer can be very refreshing.
You can see the waterfall nearby and the scenery is good.

data.formatted_address: 2435 Satogō, Higashisonogi, Higashisonogi District, Nagasaki 859-3929, Japan
data.name: Otaru Waterfall

reviews.text:
June 3, 2019
This is a waterfall on the left tributary of Otaru Falls! ️There is a promenade (mountain path), but there is a fence to prevent wild boars along the way, so you will have to climb river stones where there is a fence. ️This stone has no moss, so I didn't slip! ️There was Otaru Falls a little bit up a steep mountain road.

We recommend going during the spring cherry blossom season.
It's a place that children will also enjoy.
There is also play equipment for children to play with, so please go there once.
I think it's rare to see a waterfall that can be seen from the park. The view seems to change depending on the season, so I think it's a good place to take a walk.

reviews.text:

It is said that Hirose Tanso, a Confucian scholar of the Edo period, named the valley Ryuzusen after comparing it to a giant dragon when he was playing in Senwatani Gorge. It is a beautiful valley with 48 waterfalls and deep pools along the river. It's been a few years since I last visited, but it's still as beautiful as ever. Access: There is a way to get to the waterfall basin by going down the mountain from near the bridge over the waterfall near the plaza on the Onohara Kogen Line, and there is a parking space nearby. My recommendation is to go up along the Chiwata River from National Route 34, but be careful as the road is extremely narrow in the middle. I think the parking lot at the end could accommodate about 10 cars. In the summer, we run somen nagashi. There is a toilet on the premises. There is also a cafe and an eel Togawa fish restaurant a little downstream. The route from the parking lot to the waterfall basin is a walkway that makes use of nature and is quite thrilling. It is best to avoid wearing shoes that are slippery. The sound of the clear stream, the chirping of wild birds, and the cool breeze felt good on my slightly sweaty body.

The parking lot can accommodate about 20 cars, and the road is narrow, making it difficult to pass oncoming vehicles, but there are several shelter spots. It takes about 15 minutes from the parking lot to Ryuzusen, and the footing is poor and slippery. It was raining the day I went, so it was cloudy.

The waterfall basin at Ryuzusen is said to be over 20 meters deep.
