It's a relatively short walk from there to the park and to 99 islands. The park has nice paved walking paths with a few paths going down to the water. Although the areas by the water are mostly very rocky with lots of mussels and shellfish growth so it's not great for walking around on. There is one drinking fountain at the end of the path and nice bathrooms at the start, but no trash bins, so if picnicking remeber to bring some bags to take your trash out with you.
so nice to see a lot of small islands from the ship.

Taking a sunset sea kayak cruise in early September was a highlight of my summer. I really enjoyed the relaxing paddle out to an island and got to see a beautiful sun setting. The photos were great especially the ones with silhouette.
Great little park across from the 99 islands cruse terminal, peaceful and a great spot to get away, you have to park at the bottom of the hill cause there's no parking unless you on bike or scooter

data.name: Nagasaki Koshibyo Confucius Shrine and Historical Museum of China

reviews.text: The Confucian Shrine was constructed in 1893 and is the only one of its kind to have been built outside China. There is also a museum which showcases Chinese national cultural treasures.

It is a beautifully restored Chinese Shrine. There is a small museum at the back. All signage is in Chinese and Japanese, but there is a leaflet in English that is given to foreign visitors upon entry. It is pretty informative. The visit costs 660¥.

It’s not worth the 650 yen entrance fee (which is mostly for the museum) just wait until 5 pm and entrance will be free. Be aware if you pay for the entrance fee and go to the Museum things will not have English translation.
The shrine Itself is pretty and worth looking, but wait until 5pm

I can only speak of this Shrine during the Nagasaki Lantern festival for Chinese New Year. This Shrine was definitely the place to be to experience the different and yet blended cultures. The crowds were dense as would be expected but may also be the same during better weather months. There's a museum also attached to the shrine which was a nice addition to the overall experience. At the time admission was free.
An amazing shrine in Nagasaki glad we found it
Unique experience to visit an abandoned mining town in an island which at one point was the most densely populated places in the world.
Wonderful coal mine 😁
Unbelievable place i ever seen
Fantasy place.

I went on a lot of island trips and lighthouse trips in Korea, and this time I got to see Gunkanjima Island while traveling to a lighthouse in Japan. Even getting on the boat felt tricky. Before boarding the passenger ship, visitors will be separated and guided through verification of their Korean, Japanese, and Chinese passports. Some contents cannot be photographed. The sea route to Gunhamdo Island is not far. As you get closer to Gunkanjima, you will see Hashima Island, an island that looks like a warship in the distance. When you arrive at Gunhamdo Island, even the entrance to the island feels quite heavy. You dock the ship, cross a narrow bridge, and pass through a tunnel gateway to enter Gunhamdo Island. It feels quite stressful. When you enter the Battleship Island, the interior looks similar to the one from the Battleship Island movie. There is debris scattered here and there, and each country is divided into groups and guidance is given separately. The Korean guide's explanation is about the working environment here and what it used to be like in the old days. Nothing else is mentioned. It explains the main buildings on the island and their roles. It is said that the Japanese managers and workers lived in apartments on the ground level, and the forced laborers were not even allowed to come out on the ground level. (I heard this from another person) You cannot enter or enter the building except through the viewing passage. Entry is not permitted due to safety concerns. After a brief moment of silence and viewing, we boarded the ship. I don't know if it will be easy for Korean visitors to board passenger ships in the future.
The exhibits of artifacts unearthed during excavations at Dejima were very interesting and informative.

This was my first stop before going around Dejima. Many of the artifacts unearthed during the excavations are on display, giving a glimpse of how life was back then.
There are places where excavations are currently underway, and if there are any new discoveries, they may be put on display.
I recommend that you stop by first and then go around Dejima, as you will be able to feel the history firsthand.
Inside the stone storehouse, a large number of excavated overseas pottery items are on display.

The former Ishikura (currently the Archaeological Museum) was owned by the trading companies Hartmann Bessier (Hartmann Bessier) and Kniffrell at the end of the Edo period. It was built after the opening of the Ansei era (Bunkyu era, 1861-1864) by Hidenoshin Koyama, who also constructed Oura Cathedral and Glover House. The first floor of the archaeological museum exhibits archaeological materials such as domestic ceramics excavated from Dejima, and the second floor introduces methods for repairing and restoring Dejima's stone walls.

Excavations have uncovered many artifacts in the soil layers of Dejima and in the holes where trash was dumped.
Fragments of Imari that were exported overseas at the time, pieces of Western glass and pottery carried by Dutch ships, and pieces of Asian pottery have been unearthed.
Unearthed tiles and bricks that show what life was like back then, as well as animal bones and shells that were discarded after being eaten, give us an insight into what life was like back then.
The above is an excerpt from the pamphlet explaining the Nakano Archaeological Museum.

The former stone storehouse is said to be the western half of a stone warehouse built after the opening of the Ansei era, and was reconstructed in 1956 based on old photographs.

There were so many valuable exhibits, but unfortunately there were other places to go around so it was a bit rushed.

data.name: 長崎市中の茶屋 Naka no Chaya Teahouse

reviews.text: Beautiful garden and house in quiet residential area. Was really happy when i found this place!

It is located near Umezono Tenmangu Shrine.
Located in a residential area, the location is difficult to find.
It looks like the remains of a teahouse, but it was well maintained. I think it is one of the oldest existing buildings in Nagasaki.
It is currently the Kon Shimizu exhibition hall.
Admission to the garden is free. It seems that you can also rent a tea room.
When I have time, I would like to take my time to visit the museum (admission fee is 100 yen).
The building was destroyed in a fire, but the garden is said to be the same as it was back then. The garden was very nice.

It was a very beautiful garden. There was a shrine at the edge of the garden, which gave it a mysterious feel. Although the flowers were not in bloom, it was a fine Japanese garden.
It was free to just look at the garden, but it was 100 yen to enter the house.

The history of Christianity in Japan gives hope for the West now. For 150 years, people lived their faith creatively without any clergy. They welcomed the Western clergy back when oppression was over. So the Japanese faith is deeper and older than this Western-styled church.
A place that you should go to when in Nagasaki.  A beautiful little chapel with stained glass.  Outside the church is a walk way with lots of shops lined along it.  Must try the famous pudding there

Cash only!!! (In 2024!) bring some notes and coins.

It is not very big or special to look at itself, but it is an interesting piece of history with some detailed information in Japanese and in English.
The church is beautiful. Stained glasses are breathtaking. I strongly recommend visiting this Church.

The oldest church in Nagasaki built in 1965 as dedication to 26 martyrs of Japan. A beautiful exterior with very much european style. It has the statue of Our Lady of Japan in front of the church. Wooden dominating interior adds the sacred feeling. It's an old painting of 26 martyrs being crucified in one side of the altar. It survived the atomic bomb blast with very much eveeything in tact except for the window glasses.

If you walk for about 30 minutes from the Tanomoto bus stop, you will arrive at the castle entrance on the Atte side. You can reach the main fort without much of a difference in elevation if you go from the Edo side.
There are highlights such as Kuruwa and Karahori.
On the way back, I got off on the main side.

It is located in Yoshii Town in the northern part of Sasebo City. You can drive part way (there is a parking lot), but you have to go up the mountain. There was a toilet, but it felt a little creepy. I think it would be nice to see it as a set with Fukui Cave.
It's rare to see a castle like this that remains and has so many explanations!

The mountain path was deep, the ruins of the castle tower had an indescribable atmosphere, and that night I was in a bind. A dream in which you see four princess maids sitting side by side on your pillow, and you wake up with a red demon biting your finger? was.
Amazing! I felt the history of putting a castle 🏯 in such an amazing place.

It was a sunny day and the scenery was very scenic. We drove up to the parking lot and walked up to the historic site for about 10 minutes. I had the image of a dense forest, but it didn't feel that dark on the way, so it was better than I expected.

I walked from Imafuku Station. Walk for about 30 minutes. If you take your time climbing the gentle slope, you will arrive at the castle entrance where there is a parking lot. It takes about 10 minutes from the castle entrance.
The castle ruins had many things to see, such as the stone wall of the sub-wall with the castle monument and the information board, and the stone wall of the main gate.

I saw a sign on the way so I stopped by...but the road was so narrow!
I managed to find it using Google! The car's navigation system didn't work...

The castle is the home base of the Matsuura clan. It's a satisfying place.
You can get a panoramic view of the bay.
I wonder what kind of organization it was...Matsuura Party.

There are toilets and a parking lot near the parking lot.
Maybe because I went in the evening, the bathroom was locked. Please be careful😹💦

The signboard for the nearby ``Roadside Station Matsuura Umi no Furusatokan'' was easy to understand, so I posted it for reference.

January 3, 2024
Please note that the road is narrow enough for one car to pass according to the information board.
There is a parking lot and something that looks like a new castle.
I thought this was the castle ruins, but it turned out to be an area with toilets and a thoughtful parking lot.
There are castle ruins ahead, but it can only be reached on foot, with a moderate slope and steep stairs.
But it was worth the effort to climb up.
The view from the open site of the main shrine is spectacular.

2023/9/3
Currently, you can only drive to places where there are toilets.
From there, you can walk to Honmaru Ishigaki.
Maybe about 200m?
Along the way, it splits into the stairs on the right and the slope on the left.
It is recommended to change the course on the way there and back, but the stairway course is overgrown with grass as it is currently not maintained.
We recommend wearing clothes that are less revealing.

From the Omura City homepage,

Japan's first Kirishitan daimyo: Sumitada Omura
This castle was the residence of the Omura family in 1564.
Sumitada opened Nagasaki as a Nanban trading port,
The Tensho Embassy to Europe was sent to Rome, etc.
As a person who laid the foundation for cultural exchange between Japan and Europe.
It's famous.

Miki Castle is located where the Nagasaki Prefecture Chureito Pagoda is currently located.
As the main frame,
Large kuruwa are placed on the east and north sides,
There were also several small kuruwa.
This castle is built using the technology of building castles with stone walls in this area.
At the castle before entering,
Hirayama Castle surrounded by earthworks and a dry moat
is.
It turns out that many of the remains of the castle remain,
It is a valuable castle ruin from the end of the Sengoku period.

During the excavation, gun bullets, tea utensils,
Other daily necessities such as ceramics were also excavated.
Little by little I understand what the castle looked like at that time.
there is.

It is said to be the biggest battle at Miki Castle.
This is the battle of the 3rd year of Motoki (1572).
At this time, the Goto clan in Takeo, the Saigo clan in Isahaya,
Approximately 1,500 allied forces of the Matsuura clan from Hirado suddenly stormed the castle.
I made a surrounding attack.
However, the seven military commanders, women, and children in the castle
The great efforts of over 70 people and the success of Matasuke Tominaga,
With the desperate help of the samurai of Korimura and Kayase Village,
It is said that he achieved a great victory.
This battle is called ``Sanjo Shichiki Gomori''.

This castle was built by Sumitada's son Kizen (first lord of the Omura domain).
It was used up to
It was renovated during the Kizen era.
However, Kushima Castle was built in 1599,
Since I moved,
Its role as a castle has ended.

Kuruwa: A flat area within the castle.
A section of the castle.

I visited on a weekday.

Remains of earthworks and dry moats still remain.
Anti-Christian Junya Saigo and others were unable to conquer it.
I also understand.
In addition, including the Chureito Pagoda built on the site of the main castle,
There are several grave markers of war dead on the grounds.
Is it related to Seinan's role?
There were also items from the Kagoshima samurai tribe.

It feels very solemn and quiet.

I parked my car in the parking lot next to the first torii gate of Tomimatsu Shrine, paid a visit to the shrine, and then toured the castle ruins. There are shrines or temples around many of the castle ruins, and I always park my car in the parking lot there, so I decided to make an offering and visit with my deep gratitude and gratitude. ing.
Now, Sanjojo was the successor to Sumitada Omura (Sumitada was the second son of Haruzumi Arima, and his mother was the daughter of Sumikore Omura, so he became the adopted heir of Sumiaki Omura). Construction of the castle began in 1558 and was completed in 1564. The castle is made up of three main curves of similar elevation.

After praying, I climbed the stone steps to the right of the Ichikishima Shrine's stone torii gate and entered the Ichi-no-Kuruwa. There was a ``Nagasaki Prefecture Chureito Pagoda'' here, but I wasn't very interested in it (though I later regretted that there might have been a castle ruins monument here), so I went around to the left along the cliff of Kuruwa, and saw the three. I searched for the remains of the earthen bridge leading to Kuruwa. However, I couldn't find it because it was full of bushes, and after going around three quarters of the way around the Chureito Pagoda, I came to a cliff (cut bank) and when I tried to go down to the moat (koshikuruwa) at the bottom of the cliff, I got flustered and slipped. The relative height was about 3 to 4 meters, so I rotated sideways once and finally stopped. Fortunately, I was not injured and my body was still moving. I was injured on the first day of my 5-night, 6-day trip, but I couldn't fully regret it... I thanked God.
I gave up on the third kuruwa and headed for the second kuruwa along this moat. The second corner is a plaza, and there is an old ``Sanjo Castle Information Board'' here. From here, I headed towards San-no-Kuruwa along a narrow road, and halfway down the slope (where there are stone wall remains), I found a side road on the left that was overgrown with weeds. When you enter here, you will see the San no Kuruwa, where you can see the remains of "Miki Shrine" at the top of the cliff (stairs). There is. The inside of the building was empty and seemed to be empty.

Incidentally, Miki Castle was the Omura clan's headquarters until Sumitada Omura's son Yoshiaki moved his residence to Kushima Castle in 1599. 《Visited on July 17, 2023》


For some reason, a sheep was kept on the Sannokuruwa cliff where Miki Shrine is located. It was healthy and adorable, so I took a photo of it.

Sanjo Castle.
Built by Sumitada Omura, it served as the main castle of Sumitada's son Kizen until he moved to Kushima Castle.
The Seven Castles of the Three Castles are famous, and Takaaki Goto, Takanobu Matsuura, and Junya Saigo surrounded and attacked the three castles, but they were unable to attack and retreated.
It consists of the main enclosure, the second enclosure to the north, and the third enclosure to the southwest, and there is a large air trench from the southeast to the northeast of the enclosure.
The main keep has been turned into a tower for the faithful, and the castle marker pillar used to fall down at the entrance, but now it stands quietly next to the wash basin. When you climb up from Tomimatsu Shrine, there is a parking lot for about 3 cars at the bottom of the Chureito Pagoda.

Former Gokoku Shrine. The great guys in the old army who thought they could win by praying for something like this were so confused in their minds and strategies that they burst into tears because they felt so sorry for the people who died in the battle.

It is difficult to find the monument of the castle ruins. There are some shrines that don't even have information boards for the castle ruins. I cannot recommend it to castle lovers from other prefectures.

10 minutes walk from the castle you arrive at that beautiful 450 m long street lined with ancient samurai houses.
Some of the houses are open and visiting the interior is free.  In any case, a walk along this street is highly recommended for the relaxing atmosphere and the beautiful landscape.
Water flowing everywhere, old samurai homes you can visit, great area, come visit!

Quiet, beautiful street full of history of the lives and past of the samurai families.
Pros: This tourist attraction is free of charge, providing you access to 3 samurai houses that are preserved throughout the times. There's a tourist information centre in one of the houses where you can access the toilets and gift shop. Directions are clear as to where to go and there are some english information boards.
It's free and close to the train station. I was just stopping by for one afternoon and I enjoyed seeing inside the 3 open houses.

Nice place to stop by. It's not big and only a few houses are open to the public. So, it's not really a big tourist spot. But if you have half-an-hour to spend and want to enjoy a slow, peaceful walk in the area, it will be a good place to visit.
More like a public square than a park.
great place to spend an evening in Chinatown. This place is also used for celebrating Chinese festivals too. public toilets are available.
It's quiet place

2024.2.13 Lantern Festival
There are limited toilets, so there will be long lines.
Please note that many surrounding convenience stores will not be renting out items during this period.
Be sure to check the stage schedule. The surrounding stalls are also fun 😀

I wanted to go to a lantern with a friend from Kanto.
2024 February
I really wanted to see it and decided to go after work.
I took a wrong turn on the way 💦
We arrived 15 minutes before lights out.
I was able to take a picture of the lantern just in time.
The vermilion lanterns🏮 were really beautiful.
It was before lights out, so the nearby parking lot was empty.
lucky
Of course, Nagasaki Chinatown was over.
It gets a bit crowded on the way back in the night but otherwise it’s just great. The view is absolutely gorgeous.

The upper cable car station is very basic and does not have any shops or restaurants. From the station, it is a 5 minute walk through a cool illuminated corridor to the observatory, where you can find a restaurant (fully booked during my visit), a small gift kiosk, and the open-air rooftop with the world-famous night view. Beside the observatory there are 2 transmission antennas, which are illuminated in different colours in different seasons, and are part of a synchronised light show between sunset and 10pm.

It was very unwelcoming to Americans. They lied and said they were closed but let others through. The scenery was beyond beautiful but we shouldn’t have to argue our way Into something we want to visit.
Beautiful place!

I took a bus from my hotel to Inasayama Park, and from there I took a slope car.
This mountaintop station (Inasadake Station) was used for departure and arrival, but most people use the station below as departure and arrival.
So, although there is a ticket office, they won't issue you a ticket unless you ask, and there are no automatic ticket machines.
Additionally, all stations are becoming ticketless, and various card and cashless payments are available.

data.name: 池島炭鉱坑内体験ツアートロッコ

reviews.text: When it comes to Ikeshima, it's best to take a hands-on tour or explore the island, personally, but I'd like to recommend taking a tour around the island as a tour option at least once. The tour is guided by a former coal miner who is very good at explaining things and it's fun and feels like a field trip for adults. There's even a room that smells like the Showa era, and you won't get bored with the guide, who mixes in old stories and current situations. Hashima or Ikeshima? If you ask me, it's definitely Ikejima. Hashima tour is too bad, you can go sightseeing in Nagasaki after Tadahajima is over, but Ikeshima is the only place here.
The trolley moves slowly with a roaring sound, and the scenery is very different on the right and left sides. You can enjoy it by sitting facing different directions on your way out and back.

I participated in the afternoon tour. After watching a DVD about the history of coal mining at a former shopping center, we took a trolley to the mine. After getting off the train at the mine, you will be kindly and carefully guided by the staff, and you will be able to experience the operation of various equipment that was actually used.

data.name: Nagasaki Inasa Slope Car Summit Station

reviews.text:
This place is so underrated! It’s such a pretty spot for sightseeing!

Best if you can ride the slope car up during sunset time, else it’s still a perfect spot to have a Birds Eye view over the entire Nagasaki and admire the city lights slowly lighting up as night time approaches.

The slope car ride is definitely an interesting experience too! (Have not seen or rode on a slope car before…only cable cars…hence I found it pretty cool!) The slope cars were in 15mins frequency so it’s pretty good too!
Nice ride~ runs every 15 mins.  Great view and experience.  However, you can come down with another tram, up and down, 300 yen or 500 yen RT, to go down or walk down.
Nice ride. I helps a lot who can't walk 15 min till top (or doesn't want).
The slope car was clean and AC so very comfortable. gray sights and very reasonably priced.
Can't see much after dark.

The gardens are beautiful, either day or night the view is great. It's a quiet place with plenty of seats to enjoy good weather and scenery in a tranquil environment.
The cafe has lunch and tea. I recommend the special royal milk tea with cream, it's truly delicious.
Stunning place, great customer service, nice food, lovely views!
This is the place like Heaven! Enjoy a beautiful garden where you can have a lunch or dessert. The concept of the place it’s made by famous Japanese gardener who actually live there.

A bit odd to get to either by walking or driving (narrow streets), however totally worth. The attraction is free.

I would highly recommend the cafe attached.

This place is like a hidden treasure. You must come and see it. You can hike up to it or come by car. See it and see the view when you get here. You will not be disappointed. There is a restaurant with limited but high-quality selection of food and drinks. They’re reasonably-priced. Words fail me as I try to describe the ambience, you must feel it yourself. There are a variety of things for sale, from postcards to cups and dishes to potted plants and flowers. And know what? You don’t have to spend a single yen. You’re welcome to roam the garden for free!
Without entering Glover Garden, you can see the panoramic view of Nagasaki from the Glover Garden parking lot. Buy other delicious food with the 610 yen admission fee.

My second visit was in winter. Parking is at the municipal parking lot right in front of Shikairo Restaurant, famous for Nagasaki Champon, and then across the street to the entrance road. After the Oura Cathedral was registered as a World Cultural Heritage, admission to Oura Cathedral became a paid event, so I just saw it from afar. Other than that, nothing has changed and the two buildings are blocked off due to renovation.

This is a Japanese garden located at the end of Glover Garden. I feel like it doesn't have much of a presence due to its location. Perhaps I had visited at the wrong time, or maybe it was just before the maintenance period, but it looked more like a dense bush than a Japanese garden. There aren't that many people coming, and that may be one of the reasons, but I have high hopes for the future.

Japanese garden with a nice view
The old home of a person who educated war criminals
20200126 Plum blossoms are blooming. Is it because Nagasaki is warm? Is it because it's a warm winter?
Private property that the owners open to the public for free for one weekend every year during fall. The trees are a wonder and there's a fish pond with some very colorful fish.
Beautiful autumn leaves!

It is a wonderful garden that is well maintained. The autumn leaves were also beautiful.
It's a shame that I'm not good at taking photos and the beauty can't be fully conveyed.

2023/11/26
Gyosenkaku is a famous autumn foliage spot in Nagasaki city.
This is a facility in Nishikawasaki, a company located in Isahaya City, and is open to the public for two days a year, on the fourth Saturday and Sunday in November.
Parking is available for free at the nearby Koga Ueki Center, and it is located right next to JR Hizen Koga Station.

There is no charge for parking or admission, but it would be a waste to open the park to the public for free.
It's not as crowded as other fall foliage spots outside the prefecture, so you can take your time to view the leaves, and the garden is very well maintained.
There are height differences within the park, so wheelchairs and strollers are not allowed.
The Koga area is known as the village of garden plants, and is a place I want to go to every year, along with a walk around the area.

It is a corporate resort that is open to the public for free for two days a year (late November) during the autumn leaves season.
A well-kept garden and pond are a real treat for the eyes.
During the free public exhibition period, the nearby Koga Ueki Center will be open for free as a parking lot.
The Nishikigoi swimming in the pond have grown to an impossibly large size.

This iconic building, with its clover leaf-shaped architecture is the crown jewel of Glover Garden. It is a Nationally Designated Important Cultural Property and World Heritage Site.

Erected in 1863, it is the oldest existing Western-style wooden building in Japan. The single-storey bungalow has wide verandas, earthen walls and a roof covered with Japanese ceramic tiles. There is also a greenhouse.
Glover House and the surrounding gardens and western buildings are the most beautiful part of Nagasaki. Excellent views onto the bay.
Beautiful house with a large garden. Symbol of wealth of westerns who made it big in the past.

Excellent view of surrounding area. Some buildings were transported on site from original location but arranged as a pleasant stroll around a villa.  English guide map available but otherwise all exhibits are in Japanese.

Three nationally designated Important Cultural Properties, including the mansion of Scottish trader Thomas Blake Glover, and valuable traditional buildings scattered throughout Nagasaki City have been relocated and restored.
We are also proud of our perfect location, overlooking Nagasaki Port with Mt. Inasa in the background. Isn't it understandable that the great people who lived just after the opening of the port were fascinated by this spectacular view? From mid-July to early October, when the Western-style buildings are lit up, you can enjoy a romantic atmosphere that is different from the daytime.
You can see nine traditional buildings at Glover Garden. Among these, the Old Glover House, Old Orto House, and Old Ringer House are valuable buildings that were built during the reservation period and have continued to stand on this land for over 150 years. These three buildings are designated as nationally designated important cultural properties, and the former Glover residence is also registered as a component of the "Sites of Japan's Meiji Industrial Revolution." On the other hand, the six buildings are Western-style buildings built in Nagasaki City around the middle of the Meiji period, relocated and restored to Glover Garden. Each building has characteristics reminiscent of that time, making it a valuable building for learning about Nagasaki during the Meiji era.
Free carpark available for up to about 12 cars. Towards the top the lane narrows so drive slowly.

entry fee=free what a view! all 360° from this observation deck!  access via last stop 51 on tram line 5; then glover sky road inclined elevator; then 2nd vertical elevator that leads to or adjacent to exit 2 of glover gardens; then head south or left on road for alley stairs between houses and directly across a school playground. about 350m of paved stairs or ramps with guard rails. for the less adventurous, via taxi or car, limited parking space available at base of observation deck along with  very clean toilets.

This park is one of the famous view spot in Nagasaki City. If you use a tram, you are going to walk a little to get to the park from the Glover garden or the Ishibashi station, but, while you walk,  you can see great view of the Nagasaki Port. On the observatory, you can see The giant cantilever crane, The No.3 Mitsubishi dry dock and the Hashima island and those are world heritage sites.
It is a lovely place, I love to go there at any time, the view is always lovely and beautiful
Great view!!! Also a lovely walk up. There's a little shrine to be found too.

Magnificent hotel 🏨 recently renovated and refurbished
Located on a hillside above the harbour and smartly structured around several buildings with different functions (rooms, lounge, spa,..)
The rooms are elegantly refurbished, and the suites have a bathroom with a view
Service is welcoming and impeccable

Perched on a rocky summit overlooking a stunning view of Nagasaki city, the resort truly lives up to it 'best in Nagasaki' claim. The sushi diner is carefully prepared by the masterful chefs, and the teppanyaki dining experience is out of this world. The rooms are neat and boasts a decent view of the city.
It was an excellent stay. The room was very clean and  spacious. All the staff was very friendly and accommodating.
Stylish and well thought design of living area and guest room.   There's jaguchi in each room and beautiful view from the balcony and terrace.
This is a wonderful place to be especially in the night.. Their menu is quite delicious even though the portions are small.. It looks expensive too but the experience is well worth it.

data.formatted_address: Glover Sky Rd, ８ 上田町 長崎市 長崎県 850-0923, Japan
data.name: Glover Sky Road

reviews.text: The view up here is better than my expectations. Recommend to visit for taking nice pictures. No entrance fee and you can go up by elevator
No Tickets required. Open to Public be mindful of residents
better start the glover garden visit by taking the elevator to the top, and then walk downhill
It's a short walk from the last tram station. There is an elevator for easy access to the top. The view from above is beautiful.

After leaving the high-level exit of Glover Park, you can go to Oura Park Observation Deck and Glover SKY ROAD. Basically, the whole way is the observation deck. I can no longer tell which photo was taken where. It is certain that the angle covers the Nagasaki Port area better than Glover Park, and the circular observation deck of SKY ROAD can even take in the wonders of Nagasaki City’s mountains of private houses. Personally, I think it is a little more "climbing" than necessary. The Guoguanshan Park Observation Deck is even better for "mountain off-roading" because the scenery is not inferior to that of the top of the mountain, and you can still stay in a residential area even if you go down the mountain in the dark.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒850-0931 Nagasaki, Minamiyamatemachi, 2, グラバー通り
data.name: Gloverzaka

reviews.text: You can pick up some more souvenirs and castella cakes from the shops on your way down from Glover Garden.

To get there, you have to climb a hill and then some stairs, and it takes about 40 minutes on average to look around the park. I went there because it's a tourist spot in Nagasaki, but I'm from England, so it seemed normal to me. Mr. Glover was British, so it was great to learn about his interactions with Japan, trade, and his affinity for Japan. I knew that the Dutch lived in Nagasaki, but I had almost no knowledge of the relationship between Britain and Japan, so I think the history part of this park was the most interesting part.
There are many souvenir shops and castella shops on the slope.
Unfortunately, there were very few people, let alone tourists, and I was a little concerned about how they were doing business. I was surprised that there weren't many people in the cafe. I went in late June, so I thought there would be a few more people, but it was relatively quiet. It's a pretty beautiful garden, so I hope it will come back to life.

The slope leading to Glover Garden.
Souvenir shops are lined up from the ANA Hotel below to Glover Garden.
I was taking photos during my visit.

It is the only way to go from Shikai Tower to Oura Cathedral and Glover Garden. Along the way, there are many souvenir shops, famous Nagasaki cake shops, and dessert shops that have to queue up. You can stop by when you have time in Nagasaki.
There are many souvenir shops and the surrounding buildings are quite European-style.

data.name: さかのうえん中新町ヒルズ

reviews.text: Turn vacant land into farmland. A place where electric vegetables are grown with a wonderful view. It's fun to have conversations with the people of the town.
Incredible view, I saw it from HafH postcard so I found the place. It has a elevator-escalator (you know what I mean)

"A literal few steps" above the seemingly more popular Glover Garden - kind of 100 to 200 steps or so 😁. Taking the Glover sky road elevator up to the Glover garden level, you will need to hike a bit further up to reach the slope and stairs.

Offers a magnificent 360 degrees view of Nagasaki, 2nd only to the Mount Inasa observatory in my opinion. The best thing is - it's FOC.

The climb up the stairs was made relatively easy with a cool breeze and acceptable temperature. Looking out to the city from here, you would immediately recognize how "hilly" the city is.The city appears to have carved out of the mountainsides. Small houses, buildings, cathedrals pepper the steep slopes, creating a sort of scenery out of a painting.

Whilst this location isn't exactly a famous tourist spot. In my opinion, it should not be missed especially if you are into hiking and panoramic views.
Quite the climb for a view - it's similar to and a 1 minute walk away from Glover Skyroad but takes more effort, and has a cute little bench to sit back and watch life go by.

Oura Observatory Park is a small park located on a hill in Aioi-cho, Nagasaki City, about 300m west of the Ishibashi stop on the Nagasaki Electric Tramway.

Climb up the steep slope of ``Kenenzaka'' next to Oura Cathedral, which retains the atmosphere of a Minami-Yamate settlement that was the filming location for the movie ``Kaika'' and loved by Christian author Shusaku Endo. Oura Observatory Park is just ahead.

From the park, you can see the Higashi-Yamate townscape, including Western-style houses and the Confucius Temple, as well as Nagasaki Port.
It is lit up at night, and you can see the beautiful night view of Nagasaki, one of the world's three major night view cities.
You will walk along a narrow and intricate slope to get here, so you can enjoy the typical Nagasaki scenery. The view from the observation deck is also wonderful.
